in this way , you can arrange his legs and arms in any desired position , with feet , or one foot , barely resting on the pedestal . END

in some parts of the country , however , a co-operative movement has begun to grow , under the wing of state governments , whereby , with the financial help of the state , libraries share their book resources on a UNK or regional basis . END
new york state has what is probably the most advanced of these co-operative systems , so well developed that it has become a model for others to follow . END
because it is so large a state , with marked contrasts in population density , the organization of the new york co-operative offers a cross-section of how the plan works . END
at one extreme are the systems of upper new york state , where libraries in two or more counties combine to serve a large , UNK populated area . END
at the other are organizations like the newly formed nassau library system , in a UNK area , with ample resources and a rapidly growing territory to serve . END
both these types , and those in between , are in existence by reason of a legislative interest in libraries that began at albany as early as 1950 , with the creation by the legislature of county library systems financed by county governments with matching funds from the state . END
it was a step in the right direction , but it took an additional act passed in 1958 to establish fully the thriving systems of today . END
under this law annual grants are given to systems in substantial amounts . END
an earlier difficulty was overcome by making it clear that individual libraries in any area might join or not , as they saw fit . END
some library boards are wary of the plan . END
a large , UNK library , surrounded in a county by smaller ones , may feel that the demands on its resources are likely to be too great . END
a small library may cherish its independence and established ways , and resist joining in a cooperative movement that sometimes seems radical to older members of the board . END
within a system , however , the autonomy of each member library is preserved . END
the local community maintains responsibility for the financial support of its own library program , facilities , and services , but wider resources and additional services become available through membership in a system . END
all services are given without cost to members . END
so obvious are these advantages that nearly 95 per cent of the population of new york state now has access to a system , and enthusiastic librarians UNK the day , not too distant , when all the libraries in the state will belong to a UNK . END
to set up a co-operative library system , the law requires a central book collection of 100,000 nonfiction volumes as the nucleus , and the system is organized around it . END
the collection may be in an existing library , or it may be built up in a central collection . END
each system develops differently , according to the area it serves , but the universal goal is to pool the resources of a given area for maximum efficiency . END
the basic state grant is thirty cents for each person served , and there is a further book incentive grant that provides an extra twenty cents up to fifty cents per capita , if a library spends a certain number of dollars . END
in nassau county , for example , the heavily settled long island suburb of new york city , the system is credited by the state with serving one million persons , a figure that has doubled since 1950 . END
this system , by virtue of its variety and size , offers an inclusive view of the plan in operation . END
the nassau system recognizes that its major task it to broaden reference service , what with the constant expansion of education and knowledge , and the pressure of population growth in a metropolitan area . END
the need is for reference works of a more specialized nature than individual libraries , adequate to satisfy everyday needs , could afford . END

to the editor of the new york times : END
in your sept. 27 editorial appraisal of the work of the first session of the UNK congress you referred to the lack of `` consciousness of destiny in a time of acute national and world peril '' . END
yet your list of things left undone did not include repeal of the connally amendment to this country's domestic jurisdiction reservation to its adherence to the statute of the international court of justice . END
the connally amendment says that the united states , rather than the court , shall determine whether a matter is essentially within the domestic jurisdiction of the united states in a case before the world court to which the united states is a party . END
if the case is thus determined by us to be domestic , the court has no jurisdiction . END
since the connally amendment has the effect of giving the same right to the other party to a dispute with the united states , it also prevents us from using the court effectively . END
yet although the kennedy administration , and the eisenhower administration before it , have both declared themselves solidly for repeal of the connally amendment , as contrary to our best interests , no action has yet been taken . END
our `` destiny '' in these perilous times should be to lead strongly in the pursuit of peace , with justice , under law . END
to achieve this destiny , acts as well as words are needed -- not only acts that lead to physical strength but also acts that lead to strength based on right doing and respect . END
what better affirmative step could be taken to this end than repeal of the connally amendment -- an act which could expose the united states to no practical risk yet would put an end to our UNK attitude toward the court , enable us to utilize it , and advance in a tangible way the cause of international law and order ? ? END
we believe that the list of vital things left undone to date by the UNK congress should have included repeal by the senate of the connally amendment . END

one of the problems associated with the expressway stems from the basic idea . END
we UNK a large percentage of the cars across the river twice . END

bridges , UNK and UNK are the most common methods of river UNK . END
each one of these is , by its nature , a focal point or a point of natural congestion . END
we should avoid these congestion points or , putting it another way , keep cars starting and ending on the east side of the river -- on the east side . END
this can be accomplished by several logical steps : ( 1 ) END
widen the east river drive at least one lane . END
so widen it as to minimize the present curves and eliminate drainage problems . END
paint continuous lane stripes and install overhead directional lights as on our bridges . END
one additional lane would then be directional with the traffic burden and effectively increase the traffic carrying capability of the east river drive by fifty percent . END
this could be accomplished without the tremendous expenditures necessitated by the schuylkill expressway and without destroying the natural beauty of the east river drive . END

if we look about the world today , we can see clearly that there are two especially significant factors shaping the future of our civilization : science and religion . END

the design of a mechanical interlocking frame is much like a mechanical puzzle , but once understood , the principles can be applied to any track and signal arrangement . END
in the frame are two sets of bars which UNK with each other to prevent the operator from making dangerous moves . END
the main set of bars are the `` tappets '' and one tappet is connected to each lever . END
if the lever is pulled to clear a signal or move a switch , the tappet moves a short distance lengthwise at the same time . END
close behind the plane of the tappets are the locking bars . END
these can also move a short distance but at right angles to the tappets . END
the number of locking bars required depends on how many false moves must be prevented . END
in the sides of the tappets are notches with sloping sides , and connection between the tappets and locking bars consist of UNK called `` dogs '' . END
two or more dogs are mounted on each locking bar . END
these slide into and out of the notches in the tappets as the tappets are moved , locking and UNK them . END
here's how the scheme works : suppose the operator pulls the lever to clear a particular signal . END
this also pulls the tappet connected to the particular lever and forces any dogs seated in the notches to the side , thus moving one or more locking bars . END
the dogs on the other ends of these locking bars are thus forced into notches in other tappets . END
by this scheme , pulling one signal to clear locks all the other switch and signal levers in safe positions until the first signal is again restored to normal . END
interlocking signals are normally at stop or `` red '' position , and a lever must be pulled to `` clear '' the signal . END
this is not necessarily to green , however , for in some situations only a yellow indication is given to a train to let it into the `` plant '' . END
there are other basic rules . END
a UNK may have two levers , one to actually move the switch points , the other to lock the points . END
a signal cannot be cleared until all the related UNK are properly thrown and locked . END
such locks are nearly always used where the switch points `` face '' UNK traffic . END
the lock UNK that the points are thrown all the way with no chance that a wheel UNK will UNK on a partly thrown point . END
if the points aren't thrown all the way , the UNK cannot be locked , and in turn , the signal cannot be cleared . END
generally , these locks on UNK are called `` facing point locks '' . END
figs. UNK show typical arrangements of track and signals . END
each diagram is accompanied by a `` dog chart '' , a list of the levers that show which other levers any particular lever will lock if pulled . END
the lines connecting the UNK dogs represent the locking bars at right angles to the tappet bars . END
by studying the UNK diagrams you'll note several other details . END
UNK -- mechanical track devices that actually guide the wheels off the rails if a train passes a `` stop '' signal -- are used in many instances . END
`` home '' signals have two blades . END
the UNK blades indicate a fixed aspect -- the blade does not move . END
as an engineer approaches the plant the position of the home signal is seen in advance when he passes the `` distant '' signal located beyond the limits of the interlocking plant . END
in some UNK situations , the distant signal is fixed at caution . END
in other instances where there is no automatic block signaling , the distant has only green and yellow aspects . END
so much for the UNK . END

scientists say that the world and everything in it are based on mathematics . END
without math the men who are continually seeking the causes of and the reasons for the many things that make the world go 'round would not have any means of analyzing , UNK , and communicating the things they discover and learn . END

hot rodding is a science . END
it's not a science as involved as determining what makes the earth UNK on its axis or building a rocket or putting a satellite into orbit but it is , nevertheless , a science . END
but because science is based on mathematics doesn't mean that a hot UNK must necessarily be a UNK . END
a guy can be an active and successful hot UNK for years without becoming even remotely involved with mathematical problems ; ; END
however , he will have a clearer understanding of what he is doing and the chances are he will be more successful if he understands the few formulas that apply to rodding . END
a mathematical formula is nothing more than a pattern for solving a specific problem . END
it places the various factors involved in the problem in their correct order in relation to each other so that the influence of factors on each other can be computed . END
the first step in using a formula is to insert the numerical values of the factors involved in their correct positions in the formula . END
this changes the formula to an `` equation '' . END
the equation is used for the mathematical process of solving the problem . END
equations for rodding formulas are not complicated . END
they involve only simple mathematics that are taught in grammar school arithmetic classes . END
however , it is essential that the various mathematical symbols used in the equations be understood so that the mathematical processes can be done properly and in their correct order . END
they indicate simple division , multiplication , subtraction , and addition . END
the symbol for division is a straight line that UNK two numbers placed one above the other . END
the lower number is always divided into the upper number : af END
the symbol for multiplication is `` UNK '' . END
it is used to separate two or more numbers in a row . END
for example : af . END
numbers to be multiplied together may be multiplied in any order . END
the result will be the same regardless of the order used . END
the symbol for subtraction is the standard minus sign . END
this is nothing more than a dash . END
it UNK two or more numbers . END
the number on the right of the symbol is always subtracted from the number on the left of the symbol . END
for example : af . END
when more than two figures are separated by subtraction symbols the subtraction must be carried out from the left to right if the result is to be correct . END
for example , for the problem af , 10 from 25 equals 15 , then 6 from 15 equals 9 . END
addition is indicated by the UNK symbol . END
the symbol is used to separate two or more numbers . END
for example : af . END
numbers separated by addition symbols may be placed in any order . END
when solving an equation that involves division as well as other steps , do all the division steps first to reduce those parts of the equation to their numerical value . END
multiplication , subtraction , and addition can then be accomplished as they appear in the equation by starting at the left end of the equation and working toward the right . END
completing the division first also includes those division parts that require multiplication , subtraction , or addition steps : af . END
this would be reduced by multiplying 8 times 6 and then dividing the product by 12 . END
this part of the equation would then become 4 . END
for use in formulas , fractions should be converted to their UNK equivalents . END
the easiest way to do this is with a conversion chart . END
charts for this purpose are available from many sources . END
they are included in all types of mathematical UNK and they are stamped on some types of precision measuring instruments . END
the various mathematical processes can be simplified by carrying the results to only two or three UNK places . END
UNK the results in this manner will not have any detrimental effect on the accuracy of the final result . END
some formulas contain `` constants '' . END
a constant is a number that remains the same regardless of the other numbers used in the formula and the resultant equation . END
it is a number without which the equation cannot be solved correctly . END
rodding formulas apply to many phases of the sport . END
the answers they give can often UNK the way to performance increases and , quite often , are necessary for completing entry UNK for different events . END
when it is needed , one formula is as important as another . END

the cross-sectional area of the cylinders is determined and then the volume of the individual cylinders is computed by multiplying the area by the stroke length , which is the equivalent of the length of the cylinders . END

a UNK compression ratio is computed by comparing the UNK volume , or its displacement , with the total volume of the cylinder and its combustion chamber . END
cylinder volume can be determined mathematically but combustion chamber volume must be measured with a liquid . END
cylinder volume is determined in exactly the same manner as for the displacement formula : af . END
to measure the volume of one of the combustion chambers in the cylinder head , install the valves and spark plug in the chamber and support the head so that its gasket surface is level . END
then pour water or light oil from a graduated UNK into the chamber to fill the chamber to its gasket surface . END
do not UNK the chamber . END
this is possible with water and other liquids that have a high surface tension . END
such liquids will rise to a considerable height above the surface around the chamber before they will flow out of the chamber . END
the amount of liquid poured into the chamber is determined by UNK the quantity still in the UNK when the chamber is full from the original quantity . END

with modern techniques of UNK and the UNK of cutting tools , UNK , and attachments available , the drill press has become a basic home workshop tool . END
the drill press consists of a vertical shaft ( spindle ) which is tapered or threaded on one end to hold a drill chuck , a tubular housing ( quill ) in which the spindle is mounted , a head in which the quill is mounted , a feed lever which moves the quill up or down , a power source , and a movable table upon which the work is placed . END
there is often a means of locking the quill and , on larger presses , the table can be tilted . END
the size of the press is usually expressed in terms of chuck capacity ( the maximum diameter tool UNK it will hold ) or distance between the spindle center and the column . END
a press with an 11 inch capacity lets you drill to the center of a 22 inch board or circle . END
a new radial drill press with a 16 inch capacity has a UNK head that allows drilling to be done at any angle . END
the head is mounted on a horizontal arm that UNK on the supporting column to position the drill bit instead of the work . END
the drill press should be leveled and , depending on whether it is a bench or floor model , bolted securely to a sturdy bench or stand or screwed to the floor with UNK or expansion screws . END
this will reduce vibration and increase accuracy . END
a coat of paste wax or a UNK with a piece of wax paper will protect the polished surface of the table ; ; END
wiping with a slightly UNK cloth will discourage UNK of the column and quill . END
presses not fitted with sealed spindle bearings will need a drop of oil now and then in the UNK holes in the quill . END
the rest of the press should be kept clean by dusting with a clean rag or brush . END
be careful to keep the drive belt free of oil and grease . END
belt tension is adjusted by manipulation of two locking UNK and a movable motor mount . END
keep the belt just tight enough so the UNK won't slip when pulled by hand ; ; END
excess tension will only cause undue wear on the motor and spindle bearings . END
most drill presses have a quill return spring that raises the spindle automatically when the feed lever is released and holds the quill in the raised position . END
the return spring tension may be adjusted to suit individual requirements by gripping the spring housing with a pair of UNK ( to prevent the spring from UNK when it is released ) , UNK the lock nut or screw , and rotating the housing until the desired tension is achieved . END
turning the housing UNK will reduce tension , UNK will increase it . END
don't lose the chuck key END
some manufacturers have had the foresight to provide a UNK for the chuck key ; ; END
otherwise , you'll have to spend a few minutes to either attach a suitable spring clip somewhere on the press head or fit the key to a length of light chain and fasten to the bottom of the motor mount so that the key is out of the way when not in use . END
drill speeds are important if you want a good job . END
each cutting tool will operate best at a given speed , depending on the material worked . END
on most drill presses , it is impossible to get the exact speed , but you can come close by adjusting the drive belt on the UNK UNK . END
you will find a chart giving the various speed ratios available with your particular drill press somewhere in the instruction UNK that came with the tool . END
see the table on page 34 for exact recommended speeds . END
generally , the larger the tool and the harder the material , the slower the speed . END
feed pressure is also of major importance . END
too much pressure will force the tool beyond its cutting capacity and result in rough cuts and jammed or broken tools . END
too light a feed , particularly with metal or other hard material , causes UNK of the tool and burning of the cutting edge . END
the best results will be obtained by matching the correct speed with a steady feed pressure that lets the tool cut easily at an even rate . END
there are numerous types and styles of tools to drill holes . END
the most common are the twist drill , the solid center shaft with UNK cutting blades , the double spur bit , and the power wood bit . END
all will do a good job if sharp , but the twist drills don't cut quite as smoothly as the others , since they do not have the UNK UNK that UNK the fibers before actual boring starts . END
the UNK fly cutter is very useful for cutting large diameter holes and can be used to cut UNK discs by reversing the cutter blade . END
since fly cutters are one UNK and not balanced , they should be used at the UNK speed available , and fed very slowly to avoid binding . END
fly cutters can fool you into putting your hand too close to the tool , so if you want to avoid UNK fingers , keep your hands well out of the way . END
when drilling all the way through a UNK , always place a piece of scrap wood underneath . END
this will not only protect the work table , but also assure a clean breakthrough . END
another method of assuring a clean hole is to first drill a small pilot hole all the way through , then drill half way with the dimensional bit , turn the piece over , and finish from the other side . END
in soft woods with pronounced grain , there is sometimes a tendency for the hole to wander , due to the varying UNK of the wood . END
in this case , drilling a small pilot hole or UNK the work will do much to improve accuracy . END
when a hole is to be bored to a UNK depth , mark the depth on the side of the stock , then run the bit down so that it is even with the mark . END
the depth gauge rod can now be set , and any number of holes bored to exact and identical depth . END

-- the size of the area alone can be a determining factor . END

areas should be large enough to include the attractions , have ample space for the use of facilities needed , and have room around the edges to protect the values of the area from encroachment by private developments . END
acreage in excess of the minimum is good practice as recreation areas are never too large for the future and it is often more economical to operate one large area than several small ones . END
shape of the area is also related to the use attractions and needs of the development . END
a large picnic area or camping development is most efficient in shape as a square or rectangle several hundred feet in width in preference to a long narrow area less than one hundred feet wide . END
this is true because of savings in utility lines and the fact that your buildings have a useful radius equal in all directions . END
however , a narrow strip may be very practical for small developments , or to provide additional stream frontage for a UNK trail , or include scenic strips within the park unit . END
-- the values of the site may be affected by the appearance of the adjoining lands , ownership and use of the land , and the utilities available there . END
for instance , a site adjoining other publicly owned lands , such as a national forest or a public road , may be desirable , whereas a site next to an industrial plant might not . END
the utilities available nearby may provide a savings in the cost of extending electricity or water to the site . END
-- topography is very important . END
check the UNK of the ground , degree and direction of slopes , drainage , rock UNK , UNK types and quality , as well as UNK . END
nearly level areas are required for parking areas , beaches , camp areas , UNK , etcetera . END
determine how much topography limits useful area or what the costs of earth moving or UNK might be . END
-- in addition to its recreation interests , water is needed for drinking , sanitation , and UNK . END
the quantity and quality of water sources is often a big factor in site selection . END
the area may provide good springs or opportunities for a well or be near to municipal water lines . END
figure the cost of providing water to the use areas . END
-- the existing plant growth calls for thorough checking . END
look at the trees as to size and interest , the amount of shade they provide , how healthy they are , the problems of maintenance , fire hazards , wind throw , etcetera . END
an area may have been partially UNK and requires removal of stumps or UNK . END
some shrubs may be of good UNK value , other areas of brush may need to be cleared . END
the extent and location of open areas is noted . END
-- how much will wind , rain , sun , and temperature affect the use ? ? END
an area sheltered from strong winds may be highly desirable for recreation use . END
the direction , velocity , and season of these winds should be noted as to just how they will affect the recreation use and your maintenance and operation of the area . END
lack of UNK and extreme temperatures may call for the development of shade and UNK of a site to make it UNK . END
sometimes , you have a choice of exposure for sites where the topography or trees of the area will provide afternoon shade , morning sun , or whatever may be most desirable for the use intended . END
-- some areas may already have been improved and contain buildings , roads , utilities , cleared land , etcetera which may raise the cost of the site . END

the controversy of the last few years over whether architects or interior designers should plan the interiors of modern buildings has brought clearly into focus one important difference of opinion . END
the architects do not believe that the education of the interior designer is sufficiently good or sufficiently extended to compare with that of the architect and that , therefore , the interior designer is incapable of understanding the architectural principles involved in planning the interior of a building . END
ordinary politeness may have UNK against this opinion being stated so badly but anyone with a wide acquaintance in both groups and who has sat through the many round tables , workshops or panel discussions -- whatever they are called -- on this subject will recognize that the final , boiled down UNK of the matter is education . END
it is true that most architectural schools have five year courses , some even have six or more . END
the element of public danger which enters so largely into architectural UNK , however , would demand a prolonged study of structure . END
this would , naturally , UNK their courses far beyond the largely UNK demands of interior UNK training . END
we may then dismiss the time difference between these courses and the usual four year course of the interior design student as not having serious bearing on the subject . END
the real question that follows is -- how are those four years used and what is their value as training ? ? END
the american institute of interior designers has published a recommended course for designers and a percentage layout of such a course . END
an examination of some forty UNK of schools offering courses in interior design , for the most part schools UNK by membership in the national association of schools of art , and a further `` on the spot '' inspection of a number of schools , show their courses adhere pretty closely to the recommendations . END
one or two of the schools have a five year curriculum , but the usual pattern of american education has limited most of them to the UNK plan which seems to be the minimum in acceptable institutions . END
the suggested course of the UNK was based on the usual course offered and on the opinion of many educators as to UNK necessities . END
obviously , the four year provision limits this to fundamentals and much desirable material must be eliminated . END
without comparing the relative merits of the two courses -- architecture versus interior design -- let us examine the educational needs of the interior designer . END
to begin with , what is an interior designer ? ? END
`` the dictionary of occupational titles '' published by the u. s. department of labor describes him as follows : `` designs , plans and furnishes interiors of houses , commercial and institutional structures , hotels , clubs , ships , theaters , as well as set decorations for motion picture arts and television . END
makes drawings and plans of rooms showing placement of furniture , floor UNK , wall decorations , and determines color schemes . END
furnishes complete cost estimates for clients approval . END
makes necessary purchases , places contracts , UNK construction , installation , finishing and placement of furniture , UNK and other UNK furnishings , and follows through to completion of project '' . END
in addition to this the u. s. civil service bureau , when examining applicants for government positions as interior designers , expects that `` when various needed objects are not obtainable on the market he will design them . END
he must be capable of designing for and UNK the manufacture of any craft materials needed in the furnishings '' . END
this seems like a large order . END
the interior designer , then , must first be an artist but also understand carpentry and painting and lighting and plumbing and finance . END
yet nobody will question the necessity of all this and any reputable interior designer does know all this and does practice it . END
and further he must understand his obligation to the client to not only meet his physical necessities but also to enhance and improve his life and to enlarge the cultural horizon of our society . END
few will quarrel with the aim of the schools or with the wording of their curriculum . END
it is in the quality of the teaching of all this that a question may arise . END
the old established independent art schools try their best to fulfill their obligations . END
yet even here many a problem is presented ; ; END
as in a recent design competition with a floor plan and the simple command -- `` design a luxury apartment '' ; ; END
no description of the client or his cultural level , no assertion of geographical area or local social necessities -- simply `` a luxury apartment '' . END
working in a vacuum of minimal information can result only in show pieces that look good in UNK and UNK and may please the public relations department but have little to do with the essence of interior design . END
it is possible , of course , to work on extant or projected buildings where either architect or owner will explain their necessities so that the student may get `` the feel '' of real interior design demands . END
unfortunately , the purely synthetic problem is the rule . END
it is like medical schools in india where , in that UNK of religious inhibition , the UNK of dead bodies is frowned upon . END
instead they learn their UNK on the UNK of plants . END
thus technical efficiency is achieved at the expense of actual experience . END
in the earlier years of training certain phases of the work must be covered and the synthetic problem has its use . END
but to continue to divorce advanced students from reality is UNK . END
consultation with architects , clients , real estate men , fabric houses and furniture companies is essential to the proper development of class problems just as in actual work . END
fortunately , although only a few years ago they held the student at arms length , today the business houses welcome the opportunity to aid the student , not only from an increased sense of community responsibility but also from the realization that the student of today is the interior designer of tomorrow -- that the student already is `` in the trade '' . END
even the `` history of furniture '' can hardly be taught exclusively from photographs and lantern slides . END
here , too , the reality of actual furniture must be experienced . END
the professional organizations such as american institute of interior designers , national society of interior designers , home fashions league and various trade associations , can and do aid greatly in this work . END
certainly every educator involved in interior design should be a member and active in the work of one of these organizations . END
not only should every educator above the rank of instructor be expected to be a member of one of the professional organizations , but his first qualification for membership as an educator should be so sharply UNK that membership would be equivalent to UNK to teach the subject . END
participation for the educator in this case , however , would have to be raised to full and complete membership . END
the largest of these organizations at present denies to the full time educator any vote on the conduct and standards of the group and , indeed , refuses him even the right to attach the customary UNK after his name in the college UNK . END
this UNK status of the educator cannot fail to lower his standing in the eyes of the students . END
the professor in turn dares not tolerate the influence in his classes of an organization in the policies and standards of which he has no voice . END
this seems somewhat shortsighted since if the absolute educational qualifications for membership which the organizations profess are ever enforced , the educator will have the molding of the entire profession in his hands . END
in one way the UNK and societies do a UNK to the schools . END
that is in the continuance of the `` grandfather clauses '' in their membership requirements . END
when these groups were first formed many prominent and accomplished decorators could not have had the advantage of school training since interior design courses were rare and undeveloped during their youth . END
long hard years of `` on the job '' training had brought them to their competence . END
the necessity of that day has long disappeared . END
there is plenty of opportunity for proper education today . END
it is discouraging for students to realize that the societies do not truly uphold the standards for which they are supposed to stand . END
the reason and the day of `` grandfather clauses '' has long since passed . END
no one can deny that these `` back door '' UNK to membership provisions have been seriously abused nor that they have not resulted in the admission of downright UNK to membership in supposedly learned societies . END
beyond any question of curriculum and approach to subject must be the quality of the teachers themselves . END
it will occur to anyone that the teacher must have adequate education , a depth and breadth of knowledge far beyond the immediate necessities of his course plus complete dedication to his subject and to his students . END
the local decorator who UNK in for a few hours of teaching may but more likely may not have these qualifications . END
nor will the UNK , the UNK , still found in some of the smaller art schools , suffice . END
only a few years ago a middle western college circulated a request for a teacher of interior design . END
at the end of its letter was the information that applicants for this position `` must also be prepared to teach costume design and advertising art '' . END
this kind of UNK toward their students can scarcely build a strong professional attitude in the future designer . END
we must build a corps of highly professional teachers of interior design who have had education , experience in the profession and are willing to take on the usual UNK of teaching -- minimal income and minimal status among their UNK . END
considerable specialization in teaching subjects such as architecture , furniture design , textiles and color is also desirable . END
in all `` degree '' courses in interior design a number of `` academic '' or `` general studies '' courses are included . END
it is only fair to demand that teachers of courses in english , history , psychology and so on be as well informed in matters of art , especially interior design , as are the art teachers educated in the academic subjects . END
the proper correlation of the art with the academic can be achieved only if this standard is observed . END
the matter of sympathy of the academic professors for art objectives also must be taken into account . END
one technical question of school organization comes to mind here . END
for proper accreditation of schools , teachers in any course must have a degree at least one level above that for which the student is a candidate . END
since there are almost no schools in the country offering graduate work in interior design this rule cannot at present be observed . END
indeed , it has only been a matter of the last few years that reputable schools of art have granted degrees at all . END
the question , however , cannot be ignored for long . END
the basic problem involved is that a college setting up a graduate school must have an entirely separate faculty for the advanced degree . END
most professors in the course must , naturally , again have a higher degree than the course offers . END
one solution is the UNK of degrees in education but it is a poor substitute . END
it is a sort of academic UNK and you solve it . END
this brings us to the question of accreditation of art schools in general . END
only the independent art schools , that is , those not connected with any university or college , receive severe and separate investigation before accreditation by the various regional organizations . END
it has been the custom for most universities to stretch the blanket of accreditation for their liberal arts school to cover the shivering body of their fine arts department . END
this , plus the habit of many schools of simply adding interior design to the many subjects of their home economics department , yet , nevertheless , claiming that they teach interior design , has contributed to the low UNK of many university courses in interior design . END
in spite of this , many universities offer adequate and even distinguished courses in the subject . END
there will be no UNK of these UNK until all art schools , whether independent or attached to universities have separate accreditation -- as do medical schools -- by an art accreditation group such as the `` national association of schools of art '' . END
independent art schools granting degrees must , naturally , follow this with academic accreditation by the appropriate regional group . END

the popularity of folklore in america stands in direct proportion to the popularity of nationalism in america . END
and the emphasis on nationalism in america is in proportion to the growth of american influence across the world . END
thus , if we are to observe american folklore in the twentieth century , we will do well to establish the relationships between folklore , nationalism and UNK at the outset . END
historians have come to recognize two cardinal facts concerning nationalism and international influence . END
1 ) every age UNK the events of its history in terms of what should have been , creating legends about itself that rationalize contemporary beliefs and excuse contemporary actions . END
what actually occurred in the past is seldom as important as what a given generation feels must have occurred . END
2 ) as a country UNK its cultural and political attitudes on others , it UNK its heritage in hopes of UNK its aggressiveness . END
its folklore and legend , usually disguised as history , are allowed to account for group actions , to provide a focal point for group loyalty , and to become a cohesive force for national identification . END

the small business administration ( sba ) provides guidance and advice on sources of technical information relating to small business management and research and development of products . END
practical management problems and their suggested solutions are dealt with in a series of sba publications . END
these publications , written especially for the managers or owners of small businesses , indirectly aid in community development programs . END
they are written by specialists in numerous types of business enterprises , cover a wide range of subjects , and are directed to the needs and interests of the small firm . END
sba offers administrative management courses , which are designed to improve the management efficiency and `` know-how '' of small business concerns within a community . END
sba UNK these courses with educational institutions and community groups . END
through the UNK management counseling program , practical , UNK advice on sound management principles is available upon request to both prospective and established businessmen in a community . END
UNK conferences covering some specific phase of business management , also part of the continuing activities of the small business administration , aid community economic development programs . END
these short , `` streamlined '' meetings usually are sponsored by local banks , chambers of commerce , trade associations , or other civic organizations . END
production specialists in sba regional offices are available to help individual small business concerns with technical production problems . END

and industrial uses for agricultural products . END

this may be helpful in improving the competitive position of established firms through UNK and expansion or through more economical utilization of plant capacity . END
production specialists are available in sba regional offices to help individual small business concerns with technical production problems . END
these problems frequently arise where a firm is making items for the government not directly along the lines of its normal civilian business or where the government specifications require operations that the firm did not understand when it undertook the contract . END
production assistance often takes the form of locating tools or materials which are urgently needed . END
advice is given also on problems of plant location and plant space . END
the property sales assistance program is designed to assist small business concerns that may wish to buy property offered for sale by the federal government . END
under this program , property sales specialists in the small business administration regional offices help small business concerns to locate federal property for sale and insure that small firms have the opportunity to bid UNK for surplus personal and real property and certain natural resources , including timber from the national forests . proposed property sales of general interest to small business concerns are publicized through sba regional news releases , and by `` UNK '' directed to the small business concerns . END
each sba regional office also maintains a `` want '' list of surplus property , principally machinery and equipment , desired by small business concerns in its area . END

the farm credit administration , an independent agency located within the department of agriculture , UNK and coordinates a cooperative credit system for agriculture . END
the system is composed of three credit services , federal land banks and national farm loan associations , federal intermediate ( short-term ) credit banks , and banks for cooperatives . END
this system provides UNK and short-term credit to farmers and their cooperative marketing , purchasing , and business service organizations . END
as a source of investment capital , the system is beneficial to local communities and encourages the development of industries in rural areas . END
the credit UNK by the first two services in the system outlined above is primarily for general agricultural purposes . END
the third credit service , banks for cooperatives , exists under authority of the farm credit act of 1933 . END
the banks for cooperatives were established to provide a permanent source of credit on a sound basis for farmers' cooperatives . END
three distinct classes of loans are made available to farmers' cooperatives by the banks for cooperatives : commodity loans , operating capital loans , and facility loans . END
to be eligible to borrow from a bank for cooperatives , a cooperative must be an association in which farmers act together in processing and marketing farm products , purchasing farm supplies , or furnishing farm business services , and must meet the requirements set forth in the farm credit act of 1933 , as amended . END
interest rates are determined by the board of directors of the bank with the approval of the farm credit administration . END
for further information , contact the bank for cooperatives serving the region , or the farm credit administration , research and information division , washington 25 , d.c. . END
available , on request , from u.s. department of agriculture , washington 25 , d.c. , are : cooperative farm credit can assist in rural development ( circular no. UNK ) , and the cooperative farm credit system ( circular no. UNK ) . END
to encourage exploration for domestic sources of minerals , the office of minerals exploration ( UNK ) of the u.s. department of the interior offers financial assistance to firms and individuals who desire to explore their properties or claims for 1 or more of the 32 mineral commodities listed in the UNK regulations . END
this help is offered to applicants who ordinarily would not undertake the exploration under present conditions or circumstances at their sole expense and who are unable to obtain funds from commercial sources on reasonable terms . END
each applicant is required to own or have sufficient interest in the property to be explored . END
the government will contract with an eligible applicant to pay up to one-half of the cost of approved exploration work as it progresses . END
the applicant pays the rest of the cost , but his own time spent on the work and charges for the use of equipment which he owns may be applied toward his share of the cost . END
funds contributed by the government are UNK by a royalty on production from the property . END
if nothing is produced , there is no obligation to repay . END
a UNK royalty is paid on any production during the period the contract is in effect ; ; END
if the government UNK that production may be possible from the property , the royalty obligation continues for the 10-year period usually specified in the contract or until the government's contribution is UNK with interest . END
the royalty applies to both principal and interest , but it never exceeds 5 percent . END
information , application forms , and assistance in filing may be obtained from the office of minerals exploration , u.s. department of the interior , washington 25 , d.c. , or from the appropriate regional office listed below . END
in most of the less developed countries , however , such programing is at best inadequate and at worst UNK . END
only a very few of the more advanced ones , such as india and pakistan , have developed systematic techniques of programing . END
others have so-called development plans , but some of these are little more than lists of projects collected from various UNK while others are statements of goals without analysis of the actions required to attain them . END
only rarely is attention given to accurate progress reports and evaluation . END
we can help in the planning process END
neither growth nor a development program can be imposed on a country ; ; END
it must express the nation's own will and goal . END
nevertheless , we can UNK an aid program in such a manner as to promote the development of responsible programing . END
first , we can encourage responsibility by establishing as conditions for assistance on a substantial and sustained scale the definition of objectives and the assessment of costs . END
second , we can make assistance for particular projects UNK on the consistency of such projects with the program . END
third , we can offer technical help in the formulation of programs for development which are adapted to the country's objectives and resources . END
this includes assistance in -- assembling the basic economic , financial , technological , and educational information on which programing depends ; ; END
surveying the needs and requirements over time of broad sectors of the economy , such as transport , agriculture , communication , industry , and power ; ; END
designing the financial mechanisms of the economy in ways that will promote growth without inflation ; ; END
and administrative practices which will make possible the more effective review and implementation of programs once established . END
we must use common sense in applying conditions END
the application of conditions in the allocation of aid funds cannot , of course , be mechanical . END
it must be recognized that countries at different stages of development have very different capabilities of meeting such conditions . END
to insist on a level of performance in programing and budgeting completely beyond the capabilities of the recipient country would result in the frustration of the basic objective of our development assistance to encourage more rapid growth . END
in the more primitive areas , where the capacity to absorb and utilize external assistance is limited , some activities may be of such obvious priority that we may decide to support them before a well worked out program is available . END
thus , we might provide limited assistance in such fields as education , essential transport , communications , and agricultural improvement despite the absence of acceptable country programs . END
in such a case , however , we would encourage the recipient country to get on with its programing task , supply it with substantial technical assistance in performing that task , and make it plain that an expansion or even a continuation of our assistance to the country's development was UNK upon programing progress being made . END
at the other end of the spectrum , where the more advanced countries can be relied upon to make well thought through decisions as to project priorities within a consistent program , we should be prepared to depart substantially from detailed project approval as the basis for granting assistance and to move toward long-term support , in cooperation with other developed countries , of the essential foreign exchange requirements of the country's development program . END
the reasons for stressing self-help END
a systematic approach to development budgeting and programing is one important kind of self-help . END
there are many others . END
it is vitally important that the new u.s. aid program should encourage all of them , since the main thrust for development must come from the less developed countries themselves . END
external aid can only be marginal , although the margin , as in the case of the marshall plan , can be decisive . END
external aid can be effective only if it is a complement to self-help . END
u.s. aid , therefore , should increasingly be designed to provide incentives for countries to take the steps that only they themselves can take . END
aid advice is not interference END
in establishing conditions of self-help , it is important that we not expect countries to UNK themselves in our image . END
open societies can take many forms , and within very broad limits recipients must be free to set their own goals and to devise their own institutions to achieve those goals . END
on the other hand , it is no interference with sovereignty to point out defects where they exist , such as that a plan calls for factories without power to run them , or for institutions without trained personnel to staff them . END
once we have made clear that we are genuinely concerned with a country's development potential , we can be blunt in suggesting the technical conditions that must be met for development to occur . END
the major areas of self-help are the following : ( a ) the effective UNK of resources . END
this includes not only development programing , but also establishing tax policies designed to raise UNK resources for investment ; ; END
fiscal and monetary policies designed to prevent serious inflation ; ; END
and regulatory policies aimed to attract the financial and managerial resources of foreign investment and to prevent excessive luxury consumption by a few . END
( b ) the reduction of dependence on external sources . END
this includes UNK UNK crises , with adequate attention to reducing dependence on imports and adopting realistic exchange rates to encourage infant industries and spur exports . END
it also includes providing for the training of nationals to operate projects after they are completed . END
( c ) tapping the energies of the entire population . END
for both economic and political reasons all segments of the population must be able to share in the growth of a country . END
otherwise , development will not lead to UNK stability . END
( d ) honesty in government . END
in many societies , what we regard as corruption , favoritism , and personal influence are so accepted as consistent with the mores of UNK and so integral a part of routine administrative practice that any attempt to force their elimination will be regarded by the local leadership as not only unwarranted but unfriendly . END
yet an economy cannot get the most out of its resources if UNK , corruption , and favoritism are widespread . END
moreover , tolerance by us of such practices results in serious waste and diversion of aid resources and in the long run generates UNK sentiment of a kind peculiarly UNK to our political interest . END
some of the most dramatic successes of communism in winning local support can be traced to the identification -- correct or not -- of communist UNK with personal honesty and pro-western UNK with corruption . END
a requirement of reasonably honest administration may be politically uncomfortable in the short run , but it is politically essential in the long run . END
the united states can use its aid as an incentive to self-help by responding with aid on a sustained basis , tailored to priority needs , to those countries making serious efforts in self-help . END
in many instances it can UNK or limit its aid to countries not yet willing to make such efforts . END
there are other countries where , with skillful diplomacy , we may be able by our aid to give encouragement to those groups in government which would like to press forward with economic and social reform measures to promote growth . END
governments are rarely UNK . END
but there will be still other countries where , despite the UNK of the level of self-help , we shall UNK it wise , for political or military reasons , to give substantial economic assistance . END
even in these cases we should promote self-help by making it clear that our supporting assistance is subject to reduction and ultimately to termination . END
development requires a long-term approach END
the most fundamental concept of the new approach to economic aid is the focusing of our attention , our resources , and our energies on the effort to promote the economic and social development of the less developed countries . END
this is not a UNK goal . END
to have any success in this effort , we must ourselves view it as an enterprise stretching over a considerable number of years , and we must encourage the recipients of our aid to view it in the same fashion . END
most of our aid will go to those nearing UNK END
how long it will take to show substantial success in this effort will vary greatly from country to country . END
in several significant cases , such as india , a decade of concentrated effort can launch these countries into a stage in which they can carry forward their own economic and social progress with little or no UNK assistance . END
these cases in which light is already visible at the other end of the tunnel are ones which over the next few years will absorb the bulk of our capital assistance . END
gradually others will move up to the same level END
the number of countries thus favorably situated is small , but their peoples constitute over half of the population of the underdeveloped world . END
meantime , over the decade of the sixties , we can hope that many other countries will ready themselves for the big push into self-sustaining growth . END
in still others which are barely on the threshold of the transition into modernity , the decade can bring significant progress in UNK the slow process of developing their human resources and their basic services to the point where an expanded range of developmental activities is possible . END
aid is a long-term process END
the whole program must be conceived of as an effort , stretching over a considerable number of years , to alter the basic social and economic conditions in the less developed world . END
it must be recognized as a UNK tool designed to prevent political and military crises such as those recently confronted in laos and cuba . END
it is not a tool for dealing with these crises after they have erupted . END
the specific reasons for a long-term approach END
( a ) the need to budget a period of years . END
many of the individual projects for which development assistance is required call for expenditures over lengthy periods . END
UNK , river development schemes , transportation networks , educational systems require years to construct . END
moreover , on complex projects , design work must be completed and orders for machinery and equipment placed months or even years before construction can UNK . END
thus , as a development program is being launched , commitments and obligations must be entered into in a given year which may exceed by twofold or threefold the expenditures to be made in that year . END
the capital expansion programs of business firms involve UNK budgeting and the same is true of country development programs . END
( b ) the need to plan investment programs . END
more importantly , several of the more advanced of the less developed countries have found through experience that they must plan their own complex investment programs for at least 5 years forward and tentatively for considerably more than that if they are to be sure that the various interdependent activities involved are all to take place in the proper sequence . END
without such forward planning , investment funds are wasted because manufacturing facilities are completed before there is power to operate them or before there is transport to service them ; ; END
or a skilled labor force is trained before there are plants available in which they can be employed . END
( c ) the need to UNK country resources . END
most important of all , the less developed countries must be persuaded to take the necessary steps to UNK and commit their own resources . END
they must be induced to establish the necessary tax , fiscal , monetary , and regulatory policies . END
they must be persuaded to adopt the other necessary self-help measures which are described in the preceding section . END
the taking of these steps involves tough internal policy decisions . END
moreover , once these steps are taken , they may require years to make themselves felt . END
they must , therefore , be related to long-range development plans . END
if the less developed countries are to be persuaded to adopt a long-term approach , the united states , as the principal supplier of external aid , must be prepared to give long-term commitments . END
in this , as in so many aspects of our development assistance activities , the incentive effects of the posture we take are the most important ones . END
the extent to which we can persuade the less developed countries to appraise their own resources , to set targets toward which they should be working , to establish in the light of this forward perspective the most urgent priorities for their immediate attention , and to do the other things which they must do to help themselves , all on a realistic long-term basis , will depend importantly on the incentives we place before them . END
if they feel that we are taking a long-term view of their problems and are prepared to enter into reasonably long-term association with them in their development activities , they will be much more likely to undertake the difficult tasks required . END
perhaps the most important incentive for them will be clear evidence that where other countries have done this kind of home work we have responded with long-term commitments . END

origin of state automobile practices . END
the practice of state-owned vehicles for use of employees on business dates back over forty years . END
at least one state vehicle was in existence in 1917 . END
the state presently owns UNK passenger vehicles in comparison to approximately 200 in 1940 . END
the automobile maintenance unit , or motor pool , came into existence in 1942 and has been responsible for centralized maintenance and management of state-owned transportation since that time . END
the motor pool has made exceptional progress in automotive management including establishment of cost billing systems , records keeping , analyses of vehicle use , and UNK economies in vehicle operation . END
cars were operated in 1959 for an average UNK per mile . END
purchase of state vehicles is handled similarly to all state purchases . END
unit prices to the state are considerably lower than to the general public because of quantity purchases and no payment of state sales or federal excise taxes . END
vehicle purchase , assignment and use policies . END
the UNK role in policy determination concerning state-owned vehicles has been confined almost exclusively to UNK funds for vehicles . END
the meaningful policies governing the purchase , assignment , use and management of state vehicles have been shaped by the state's administrative officers . END
meaningful policies include : ( a ) kinds of cars the state should own , ( b ) when cars should be traded , ( c ) the need and assignment of vehicles , ( d ) use of cars in lieu of mileage allowances , ( e ) employees taking cars home , and ( f ) need for liability insurance on state automobiles . END
a review of these policies indicates : ( 1 ) END
the state purchases and assigns grades of cars according to need and position status of driver and use of vehicle . END
the purchase of compact ( economy ) cars is being made currently on a test basis . END
cars are traded mostly on a three-year basis in the interest of economy . END
the factors governing need and assignment of cars are flexible according to circumstances . END
unsuccessful efforts have been made to replace high mileage allowances with state automobiles . END
it is reasonably economical for the state to have drivers garage state cars at their homes . END
the state has recently undertaken liability insurance for drivers of state cars . END
automobile practices in other states . END
a survey of practices and/or policies in other states concerning assignment and use of state automobiles reveals several points for comparison with rhode island's practices . END
forty-seven states assign or provide vehicles for employees on state business . END
two other states provide vehicles , but only with legislative approval . END
states which provide automobiles for employees assign them variously to the agency , the individual , or to a central pool . END
twenty-six states operate a central motor pool for acquisition , allocation and/or maintenance of state-owned vehicles . END
nineteen states report laws , policies or regulations for assigning state vehicles in lieu of paying mileage allowances . END
of these states the average `` UNK '' point ( at which a car is substituted for allowances ) is UNK miles per year . END
mileage allowances for state employees are of two types : ( a ) actual mileage and ( b ) fixed monthly allowances . END
actual mileage allowances are UNK UNK allowed employees for the use of UNK vehicles on state business at the rate of UNK per mile . END
fixed monthly allowances are UNK for the same purpose except on a UNK basis . END
both allowances are governed by conditions and restrictions set forth in detail in the state's travel regulations . END
rhode island's UNK rate of UNK per mile for use of UNK cars compares favorably with other states' rates . END
the average of states' rates is UNK per mile . END
rhode island's rate of UNK per mile is considerably lower than UNK rates in the federal government and in industry nationally which approximate a UNK per mile average . END
actual mileage allowances are UNK and not unduly expensive for the state . END
the travel regulations , requirements and procedures governing UNK are controlled properly and not overly restrictive . END
fixed monthly allowances are a controversial subject . END
they have a great advantage in ease of audit time and payment . END
however , they lend themselves to abuse and inadequate control measures . END
flat payments over $50 per month are more expensive to the state than the assignment of state-owned vehicles . END
travel allowances , including subsistence , have been revised by administrative officials recently and compare favorably with other states' allowances . END
with few exceptions travelers on state business are allowed actual travel expenses and $15 per day subsistence . END
travel allowances are UNK and pose little problem in administration and/or audit control . END
origin of state automobile practices END
it is difficult to pinpoint the time of origin of the state purchasing automobiles for use of employees in rhode island . END
few records are available concerning the subject prior to 1940 . END
those that are available shed little light . END

the best reason that can be advanced for the state adopting the practice was the advent of expanded highway construction during the 1920s and UNK . END
at that time highway engineers traveled rough and dirty roads to accomplish their duties . END

history and operation of the motor pool . END
while the origin of state-owned automobiles may be obscured , subsequent developments concerning the assignment , use , and management of state automobiles can be related more clearly . END

the rhode island property tax END
there was a time some years ago when local taxation by the cities and towns was sufficient to support their own operations and a part of the cost of the state government as well . END
for many years a state tax on cities and towns was paid by the several municipalities to the state from the proceeds of the general property tax . END
this tax was discontinued in 1936 . END
since that time the demands of the citizens for new and expanded services have placed financial burdens on the state which could not have been foreseen in earlier years . END
at the same time there has been an UNK and expansion of municipal services as well . END
thus , there has come into being a situation in which the state must raise all of its own revenues and , in addition , must give assistance to its local governments . END
this financial assistance from the state has become necessary because the local governments themselves found the property tax , or at least at the rates then existing , insufficient for their requirements . END
consequently there have developed several forms of UNK and shared taxes , as well as the UNK grant to local governments for general purposes whose adoption accompanied the introduction of a sales tax at the state level . END
notwithstanding state aid , the local governments are continuing to seek additional revenue of their own by strengthening the property tax . END
this is being done both by the UNK of real property and by seeking out forms of personal property UNK neglected or ignored . END
taxation of tangible movable property in rhode island has been generally of a `` hands off '' nature due possibly to several reasons : ( 1 ) local assessors , in the main , are not well paid and have inadequate office staffs , ( 2 ) the numerous categories of this component of personal property make locating extremely difficult , and ( 3 ) the UNK of the majority of assessors in evaluating this type of property . END
problems of taxing personal property . END
among the many problems in the taxing of personal property , and of movable tangible property in particular , two are significant : ( 1 ) situs , ( 2 ) fair and equitable assessment of value . END
these problems are not local to rhode island , but are recognized as common to all states . END
although the laws of the various states , in general , specify the situs of property , i.e. , residence or UNK of the owner , or location of the property , the exceptions regarding boats , airplanes , mobile homes , etc. , seem to add to the uncertainty of the proper UNK point for assessment . END
rhode island law specifies that all real estate is taxable in the town in which it is situated . END
it also provides for the taxation of all personal property , belonging to inhabitants of the state , both tangible and intangible , and the tangible personal property of UNK in this state . END
in defining personal property , it specifically mentions `` all ships or vessels , at home or abroad '' . END
intangible property is taxable wherever the owner has a place of abode the greater portion of the year . END
although a similar situs for tangible property is mentioned in the statute , this is UNK out by the provision that definite kinds of property `` and all other tangible property '' situated or being in any town is taxable where the property is situated . END
this would seem to fix the tax situs of all movable personal property at its location on december 31 . END
both boats and aircraft would fall within this category , as well as motor vehicles . END
the location of the latter now is determined for tax purposes at the time of registration , and it is now accepted practice to consider a motor vehicle as being situated where it is UNK . END
obviously , it would be impossible to determine where every vehicle might be on the UNK day of december . END
in view of the acceptance accorded the status of motor vehicles for tax purposes , in the absence of any specific provision it would seem entirely consistent to apply the same interpretation to boats or aircraft . END
a recent example of this problem is the flying of six airplanes , on december 31 , 1960 , from the newport UNK in UNK , to the north central airport in UNK . END
this situation resulted in both towns claiming the tax , and probably justifiably . END
UNK bases its claim on the general provision of the law that `` all UNK property , both tangible and intangible , shall be taxed to the owner thereof in the town in which such owner shall have had his actual place of abode for the larger portion of the twelve ( 12 ) months next preceding the first day of april in each year '' . END
the UNK tax UNK , in turn , claims the tax under the provision of law `` and all other tangible personal property situated or being in any town , in or upon any place of storage shall be taxed to such person in the town where said property is situated '' . END
this problem of fair and equitable assessment of value is a difficult one to solve in that the determination of fair valuation is dependent on local assessors , who in general are UNK and part-time personnel taking an individualistic approach to the problem . END
this accounts for the wide UNK in assessment practices of movable tangible property in the various municipalities in rhode island . END
this condition will undoubtedly continue until such time as a state uniform system of evaluation is established , or through mutual agreement of the local assessing officials for a method of standard assessment practice to be adopted . END
the rhode island public expenditure council in its publication once commented : `` END
the most realistic way of facing up to this problem would be to have the state take over full responsibility for assessing all taxable property . END
an adequately UNK and equipped state assessing office could apply uniform methods and standards which would go far toward producing equitable assessments on all properties throughout the state . END
a single statewide assessing unit would eliminate the differences and complications that are inherent in a system of 39 different and independent assessing units '' . END
the institute of public administration , in its report to the state fiscal study commission in 1959 , recommended `` UNK and UNK all aspects of property tax administration in a single state agency professionally organized and equipped for the job '' . END
the resulting setup , it was declared , `` would be similar to that which is in successful operation in a number of metropolitan counties as large or larger than rhode island '' . END
practices in rhode island . END
to determine the practice and attitude of municipal governments concerning tangible movable property , a questionnaire was sent to all local government assessors or boards of assessors in rhode island . END
the replies from each individual town are not given in detail because the questions asked the personal opinion of the several assessors and are not necessarily the established policy of the town in each case . END
there are legitimate reasons for differences of opinion among the assessors as a whole and among the public officials in each town . END
these opinions of the assessors are of significance in indicating what their thinking seems to be at the present time . END
in reply to a question of whether they now tax boats , airplanes and other movable property excluding automobiles , nineteen said that they did and twenty that they did not . END
the wording of the question was quite general and may have been subject to different interpretations . END
one UNK checked boats only , another trailers and tractors , one mentioned house trailers , and two others referred to trailers without UNK the type . END
in two cases , airplanes only were indicated . END
it is difficult to UNK exactly what was meant in each individual situation , but the conclusion may be drawn that 21 towns do not assess movable personal property , and of the remainder only certain types are valued for tax purposes . END
boats were indicated specifically by only one of the five towns known to tax boats . END
it would seem , then , that movable property and equipment is not taxed as a whole but that certain types are taxed in towns where this is bound to be expedient for that particular kind of personal property . END
so few answered the question relating to their efforts to assess movable property that the results are UNK . END
only four towns indicated that they made any more than a normal effort to list property of this kind . END
of greater interest is a question as to whether movable property was assessed according to its location or ownership . END
fifteen stated that it was according to location , four by residence of the owner , and nineteen did not answer . END
UNK assessors stated that they were in favor of improved means for assessing movable personal property , and only five were opposed . END
seven others expressed no opinion . END
on this point there was fairly general agreement that assessors would like to do more than they are doing now . END
it is not clear , however , whether they are thinking of all movable property or only of boats , trailers , aircraft or certain other types of personal property whose assessment would be advantageous to their particular towns . END
another question that was asked of the assessors was whether they favored the assessment of movable property at its location or at the residence of the owner . END
eighteen voted for assessment by the town in which it is located and eleven preferred assessment by the town in which the owner resides . END
ten others made no reply . END
of those who have an opinion , it seems that assessment by location is preferred . END
there was one vote for location being the place where the property is situated for the greater portion of the twelve months preceding the assessment date . END
to UNK , it may be said that there is no one prevailing practice in rhode island with respect to the taxation of movable property , that assessors would like to see an improvement , and of those who have an opinion , that assessment by the town of location is preferred on the basis of their present knowledge . END
the need for greater knowledge is evident from their replies . END
interest has been shown for a number of years by local assessors in the possibility of taxing boats . END
assessors in rhode island are charged not only with placing a valuation upon real and personal property , but they also have the responsibility to raise by a tax `` a sum not less than nor more than '' a specified amount as ordered by a city council or financial town meeting . END
it has been obvious to the assessors , particularly those in shore communities , that boats comprise the largest category of tangible personal property which they have been unable to reach . END
through their professional organization , the rhode island tax officials association the question of taxing boats long has been debated and discussed . END
no satisfactory solution has been found , but this is due more to the difficulties inherent in the problem than to a lack of interest or UNK on the part of the assessors . END
it has been estimated that the value of boats in rhode island waters is something in excess of fifty million dollars , excluding commercial boats . END
it is obvious that this is a potential and UNK source of revenue for the assessors of those towns where a substantial amount of such property would be subject to taxation . END
it is known that at least five towns ( UNK , UNK , narragansett , newport and westerly ) place some value on some boats for tax purposes . END
however , few are taxed , and the owners and location of most boats are unknown to the assessors on the date of assessment of town UNK . END
no one really knows how many boats there actually are or what their aggregate value may be . END
slightly more than 5,000 boats were registered with the coast guard prior to the recent passage of the state boating law . END
only a few more than 10,000 boats had been registered with the division of UNK and rivers at the end of the 1960 boating season , but many had been taken out of the water early when the threat of a hurricane brought the season to an early close . END
the UNK association , meeting at narragansett in september 1960 , devoted its session to a discussion of the boat problem . END
