stated in its simplest terms , the main job of the planning division is to plan for the future of the state of rhode island . END
the activities of the planning division are defined in considerable detail in the enabling act of the development council , which assigns to the agency both broad responsibilities and specific duties in the field of planning . END
two years ago , the institute of public administration issued an extremely comprehensive report entitled `` UNK relations in metropolitan rhode island . END
as the result of an UNK review of the recommendations contained in this report , plus an analysis of our own enabling act , the planning division developed a number of basic planning objectives which caused a UNK of its work program . END
these objectives are stated here because of their importance in understanding the current activities of the planning division . END
first priority will be given to the preparation of a meaningful state guide plan to serve as a background for all other planning activities in the state . END
recognizing the truth of the statement by the institute of public administration that `` UNK planning ( in rhode island ) means , or should mean , state planning '' , the state guide plan will take into account the metropolitan nature of many of rhode island's problems . END
it will continue to be an objective of this division to encourage the acceptance of planning as a proper and continuing responsibility of local government . END
to this end , the community assistance program of the planning division will continue to be operated as a staff function to make available , on a shared cost basis , technical planning assistance to those communities in the state unable to maintain their own planning staff . END
the planning division will take the initiative in encouraging planning cooperation at all levels of government ; ; END
among the operating departments of the state ; ; END
between the cities and towns of the state ; ; END
and on a regional basis between the six new england states . END
on the basis that all citizens of the state are entitled to benefit equally in the development of its resources , plans for the provision of essential services ( such as water ) will be based on need regardless of arbitrary political boundaries , within the framework of the state plan . END
the state development budget will reflect the capital needs of all the state agencies and the priority of the projects in the budget will be based on the state plan . END
in preparing the state guide plan , particular attention will be given means of strengthening the economy of the state through the development of industry and recreation . END
functionally the planning division carries out four activities : long-range state planning , current state planning , local planning assistance ; ; END
and the preparation of the state development budget . END
the planning division has UNK on the most complete and comprehensive state planning program in the nation . END
the long-range aspects of this program are divided into four distinct phases : basic mapping , inventory , analysis and plan and policy formation . END
the work program , as it was originally proposed , was to take five years to complete . END
recent events -- particularly the necessity of providing planning information for the statewide UNK study of the department of public works -- indicate that this schedule will have to be accelerated . END
the basic mapping phase of the program has been completed and the inventory phase is scheduled for completion july 1 , 1961 . END
since accurate base maps are necessary for any planning program , the first step taken by the planning division to implement the long-range state plan has been to prepare two series of base maps -- one at a scale of 1 inch to a mile , and the second a series of 26 sheets at a scale of 1 inch to 2000 feet , covering the entire state . END
with these maps completed , the inventory phase of the plan has been started . END
with the aid of matching federal funds available under section UNK of the housing act of 1954 as amended , the planning division began a one year program july 1 , 1960 to complete the inventory phase of the state planning program . END
this phase consists of four items : urban land use , rural land use , physical features and public utility service areas . END
since the validity of all subsequent planning depends on the accuracy of the basic inventory information , great care is being taken that the inventory is as complete as possible . END
the urban land use study carried out by the planning division staff has consisted of UNK and mapping all urban land uses which are of significance to statewide planning . END
the rural land use study is being carried out under contract by the university of rhode island and identifies all agricultural land uses in the state by type of use . END
the mapping of important physical features such as slopes and types of soil and the collection of all available information pertaining to public utility service areas are being conducted as staff projects and , like the other two inventory projects , are scheduled for completion july 1 , 1961 . END
the collection of information is meaningless unless it is understood and used for a definite purpose . END
special districts in rhode island . END
it is not within the scope of this report to elaborate in any great detail upon special districts in rhode island . END
however , a word should be mentioned in regard to them as independent units of government . END
there are forty-seven special district governments in rhode island ( excluding two regional school districts , four housing authorities , and the kent county water authority ) . END
these forty-seven special purpose governments have the authority to levy taxes , to borrow money , own property , sue and be sued , and in general to exercise normal corporate powers . END
unlike cities and towns , however , they do not have to submit any financial statements to the state bureau of UNK . END
it is not an exaggeration to say that the state government has little or no fiscal control over these units of government . END
in addition to the collection of service charges , the special districts levy annual property taxes of approximately UNK . END
fiscal years in other states END
a review of practices in other states regarding fiscal uniformity is pertinent to this report . END
included in the findings are : 1 . END
UNK states , including rhode island , end their fiscal year on june 30 . END
the other four states end on varying dates : alabama ( sept. 30 ) , new york ( march 31 ) , pennsylvania ( may 31 ) , and texas ( august 31 ) . END
in sixteen states , the fiscal year ending of the cities ( june 30 ) is the same as that of the state : alaska , arizona , california , delaware , massachusetts , UNK , nevada , new mexico , north carolina , north dakota , oklahoma , oregon , vermont , west virginia , wyoming , and hawaii ) . END
in eleven states , the fiscal year of the cities ends on december 31 , while the state fiscal year ends on june 30 ( arkansas , colorado , indiana , kansas , new hampshire , new jersey , ohio , south dakota , utah , washington , and wisconsin ) . END
in eight states whose fiscal years close on june 30 , a majority of their cities close their fiscal year on december 31 : : END
( georgia , iowa , kentucky , maine , maryland , minnesota , virginia , and south carolina ) . END
one state , alabama , closes its fiscal year on september 30 , and all cities in the state , with one exception , also close fiscal years on september 30 . END
mississippi closes its fiscal year on june 30 , while all of its cities close their fiscal years on september 30 . END
pennsylvania closes its fiscal year on may 31 . END
all of its cities close their fiscal years on december 31 . END
the remaining twelve states have varying fiscal years for the state , city and local governments . END
however , only illinois , oregon , louisiana and rhode island have a situation in which the sundry units of government vary widely in relation to fiscal uniformity . END
fiscal uniformity : advantages and disadvantages END
an excellent summary of advantages concerning the uniform fiscal year and coordinated fiscal calendars was contained in a paper presented by a public finance authority recently . END
he listed among the values of fiscal uniformity : 1 . END
the uniform fiscal year requires compliance with common sense administration of local finances : adoption of the budget , or financial plan , in advance of spending . END
the uniform fiscal year UNK UNK with another common sense rule , that of having cash in the bank before checks are drawn . END
it enables towns to make more economical purchases and to take advantage of cash discounts . END
the uniform fiscal year promotes more careful budgeting and strengthens control over expenditures . END
by fixing the tax rate in advance of spending , upper limits are set on expenditures . END
the uniform fiscal year brings the town's fiscal year into line with that of the schools , which UNK the largest share of local UNK . END
this greatly UNK the town's bookkeeping and financial reporting . END
the uniform fiscal year eliminates interest charges on money borrowed in the form of tax anticipation notes . END
furthermore , tax collections not immediately needed for current expenditures may be invested in short-term treasury notes , UNK the town's miscellaneous revenues and reducing the tax levy . END
the uniform fiscal year UNK UNK comparison of revenues and expenditures . END
when towns have the same fiscal year it is relatively easy to make meaningful comparisons ; ; END
and as the cost of local government increases , the demand for such comparison also increases . END
towns having different fiscal years are difficult to compare . END
of all advantages , probably none is more important than the elimination of tax anticipation notes . END
borrowing in anticipation of current taxes and other revenues is a routine procedure of the majority of municipalities at all times . END
it may be by bank loans , sale of notes or warrants , or by the somewhat casual method of issuance and registration of warrants . END
in any event it is a form of borrowing which could be and should be rendered unnecessary . END
its elimination would result in the saving of interest costs , heavy when short-term money rates are high , and in freedom from dependence on credit which is not always available when needed most . END
this type of borrowing can be reduced to a minimum if quarterly installment payment of taxes is instituted and the first payment placed near the opening of the fiscal year . END
any approach toward such a system looks toward saving and security . END
it should be noted that there are other and equally important reasons for establishing meaningful UNK reporting bases on a uniform fiscal year . END
both the federal and state governments UNK their fiscal years on july 1 . END
both units of government contribute increasingly large sums of money to the several local governments in this state as indicated below : END
it has been said that when local government revenues were mostly produced locally from the property tax , the lack of a uniform fiscal year was no great handicap ; ; END
but with the growth of state and federal fiscal aid , the emphasis on UNK , and the UNK sharing of responsibility for certain important functions , this is no longer true . END
the UNK fiscal year calendar is an obstacle to the planning of clear and efficient UNK revenue and expenditure relationships . END
although there are many sound reasons for adopting uniform and coordinated fiscal years in rhode island , there are also certain difficulties encountered . END
these involve more the mechanics employed in adjusting to fiscal uniformity than they do actual disadvantages to the principle . END
one problem is a matter of shifting dates ; ; END
the other , is how to finance the transition . END
little can be done about the changing of dates . END
this is an inherent part of adjusting fiscal calendars . END
it usually means a confused and UNK UNK public for a period of time . END
but cooperation and understanding between local officials and the UNK help lessen this problem . END
the other problem is the matter of financing the transition period in the several cities and towns . END
this will be covered more fully later . END
it should be kept in mind that the ease or difficulty with which a town or city can convert to the proposed plan is directly dependent upon the financial condition of that town or city . END
fortunately , there are no cities or towns in the state , with one or two possible exceptions that are in too difficult a position to finance the proposed change . END
sacrifice will have to be made in some cases , but it is to the UNK advantage to finance the UNK for a short period of time rather than pay interest on tax anticipation notes indefinitely . END
the advantages of a uniform fiscal year and well UNK fiscal and tax collection calendars are sufficiently great for rhode island municipalities to exert effort to secure them . END
the type of program desired can be determined by the nature and extent of the adjustments needed . END
two features are immediately evident . END
first , the present situation is too varied to be UNK by any single formula . END
second , the shift to a uniform july 1 to june 30 fiscal year will , of itself , improve the tax collection calendars of the great majority of cities and towns . END
there are at least two problems to consider : one is a matter of adjusting the fiscal calendar ; ; END
the other is how to finance the adjustments when necessary . END
the latter matter is considered in detail in a later section . END
twelve cities and towns in rhode island presently indicate some plans to establish a uniform and/or coordinated fiscal tax year calendar . END
plans vary from the `` talking stage '' to establishing special committees to accomplish this end . END
what is important here is that many of the cities and towns recognize the need for improved fiscal practices and are taking the initiative to obtain them . END
an analysis of the fiscal tax collection year calendars throughout the state indicates that transition may not be as painful as is commonly thought . END
however , it must be stressed that much depends upon the financial condition of the individual cities and towns involved . END
the adjustments needed to establish a uniform and coordinated fiscal tax collection year calendar throughout rhode island , based on a july 1 to june 30 year , are shown below . END
six cities and towns are presently on a july 1 to june 30 fiscal year and have coordinated their tax collection year with it . END
no change is required for these towns . END
these municipalities include : UNK , lincoln , UNK , newport , north UNK , and south UNK . END
adjustment of fiscal year . END
one town and one city , UNK and east providence , require an adjustment of their fiscal year only . END
this change will automatically adjust their tax collection year calendar so as to make all tax UNK due and UNK in the fiscal year UNK within that year . END
adjustment of tax collection year . END
six cities and towns are now on a july 1 to june 30 fiscal year and will need only to adjust their tax collection year calendar to establish uniformity . END
these cities and towns include UNK , UNK , UNK , UNK , central falls , and woonsocket . END
two cities to be considered , providence and cranston , are an enigma . END
both have excellent integration of their fiscal tax collection year calendars . END
however , neither of these two cities is on the desired july 1 to june 30 fiscal year . END
the adjustment to a uniform and coordinated fiscal period could be accomplished relatively easily for them . END
in that both cities end their fiscal years on september 30 , they could levy taxes for an interim period of nine months , commencing with september 30 and ending with june 30 . END
these three installment dates would be : october 26 , january 26 , and april 25 ( providence ) and november 15 , february 16 and may 15 ( cranston ) . END
both would start their new fiscal year on july 1 . END
their tax collection calendar could then be : july 25 , october 26 , january 26 , and april 25 , ( providence ) ; ; END
and august 15 , november 15 , february 17 , and may 15 , ( cranston ) . END
under this plan both cranston and providence would be on the uniform fiscal year but would still be using the same installment periods . END
the remaining twenty-three towns have fiscal years which end prior to june 30 . END
all of these towns will require adjustments of both their fiscal and tax collection years . END
assuming an adjustment to the july 1 to june 30 fiscal year , the required adjustment of the tax collection years and the towns involved are shown in table 3 . END
aside from the matter of adjusting the fiscal and tax calendars , there is the problem of financing the adjustment when this is necessary . END
it should be emphasized strongly that adjustments in fiscal dates or adoption of interim budgets do not necessarily mean financing over and above normal governmental requirements . END
in many communities there is simply no financial problem ; ; END
it is only a matter of adjusting accounting methods , careful fiscal planning and management , or some like combination of techniques . END
in other municipalities the difficulties in overcoming the financial burden have been sufficiently great to UNK proponents of fiscal year changes . END
fortunately , such cases in rhode island are more the exception than the rule . END
as shown earlier in table 1 , the several cities and towns use widely varied fiscal and tax collection calendars . END
in addition , no two rhode island communities are identical in relation to their over-all financial condition . END
these factors practically insure that no single financing formula is feasible ; ; END
each situation must be studied and a plan developed that takes into consideration such factors as the effect of the existing and prospective tax calendars , the financial condition of the UNK , and the length of the transition interval . END
suitable plans range from those that are very easy to develop to those that are difficult to formulate and require borrowing ranging from short-term serial notes to long-term bonds . END
the financial problem , where it exists , usually stems from the adoption of a budget for the transitional or adjustment period . END
for those communities which have financial difficulties in UNK adjustments , there are a number of alternatives any one of which alone , or in combination with others , would minimize if not even eliminate the problem . END

proclamation thanksgiving day by john a. notte , jr. , governor END
as another thanksgiving draws near , let us take time out from the often UNK pace of our lives to try and UNK the feelings that filled the hearts of the pilgrims on the first thanksgiving . END
the pilgrims gathered to thank the lord for his benevolence during their first year in the new land . END
they had been through trying times , but their faith in the almighty had given them the courage and the strength to meet and overcome the many problems and difficulties that were the price they had to pay for freedom . END
and as the pilgrims bowed their heads in humble gratitude , they shared another feeling -- the anticipation of what the future held for them and their posterity . END
they could not guess that from their concepts of liberty and freedom would some day be born a new nation that for years would be the symbol of hope to the oppressed countries of the world . END
they simply turned to god filled with gratitude and faith . END
we who are living today may learn a valuable lesson from those who celebrated the first thanksgiving day . END
the lord has shown time and time again his love for us . END
we have only to compare the liberty and high standard of living we enjoy in this great country with the oppression and UNK of other nations to realize with humble gratitude that god's providence has been with us since the very beginning of our country . END
and yet , accompanying our gratitude is the realization that we are living in a crucial time . END
with world peace constantly being threatened , most of us regard the future UNK , and even with fear . END
it is at this time that we should imitate the pilgrims by accompanying our prayers of thanks with the conviction that we shall continue to be in UNK need for the lord's protection in the future , if we are to have peace ; ; END
now , therefore , do i , john a. notte , jr. , governor of the state of rhode island and providence plantations , proclaim thursday , november UNK , 1961 , as thanksgiving day , END
and so , let us remember on this day not only to thank the almighty who gave hope and courage to the pilgrims , but also to place our trust in him that he will continue to protect us in the future as he has in the past . END

the causes of the decline of the commuter railroads are many and complex -- high taxes , losses of revenue to government subsidized highway and air carriers , to name but two . END
and the solutions to the problems of the commuter lines have been equally varied , ranging all the way from government ownership to complete UNK of this important service . END

at this time of crisis in our nation's commuter railroads , a new threat to the continued operations of the new york central has appeared in the form of the chesapeake & ohio UNK proposal for control of the baltimore & ohio railroads . END
the new york central has pointed out that this control , if approved by the interstate commerce commission , would give the combined c. & o. - b. & o. railroad a total of UNK points served in common with the new york central . END
not only is this kind of duplication wasteful , but it gives the combined system the ability to take freight traffic away from the new york central and other railroads serving the area . END
the new york central notes : `` END

these revenues make it possible to provide essential freight and passenger service over the entire new york central system as well as the new york area commuter and terminal freight services . END
if these services are to be maintained , the new york central must have the revenues to make them possible '' . END
the new york central today handles 60 percent of all UNK commuter traffic coming into new york city . END
this is a UNK million operation involving UNK employees who work on commuter traffic exclusively . END
a blow to this phase of the UNK operations would have serious economic consequences not only to the railroad itself , but to the 40,000 people per day who are provided with efficient , reasonably priced transportation in and out of the city . END
there is a workable alternative to this potentially dangerous and UNK c. & o. - b. & o. merger scheme '' -- END
the central has pointed out . END

detailed studies of the plan were well UNK . END

from its inception in 1920 with the passage of public law UNK , UNK congress , the purpose of the vocational rehabilitation program has been to assist the states , by means of UNK , to return disabled men and women to productive , UNK employment . END
the authority for the program was renewed several times until the vocational rehabilitation program was made permanent as title 5 , of the social security act in 1935 . END
up to this time and for the next eight years , the services provided disabled persons consisted mainly of training , counseling , and placement on a job . END
recognizing the limitations of such a program , the UNK congress in 1943 passed p. l. UNK , which broadened the concept of rehabilitation to include the provision of physical restoration services to remove or reduce UNK , and which revised the financing structure . END
despite the successful rehabilitation of over a half million disabled persons in the first eleven years after 1943 , the existing program was still seen to be inadequate to cope with the nation's backlog of an estimated two million disabled . END
to assist the states , therefore , in UNK handicapped individuals , `` so that they may prepare for and engage in UNK employment to the extent of their capabilities '' , the UNK congress enacted the vocational rehabilitation amendments of 1954 ( p. l. UNK ) . END
these amendments to the vocational rehabilitation act were designed to help provide for more specialized rehabilitation facilities , for more sheltered and `` half-way '' workshops , for greater numbers of adequately trained personnel , for more comprehensive services to individuals ( particularly to the UNK and the blind ) , and for other administrative improvements to increase the UNK overall effectiveness . the provisions are also designed to avoid UNK in state programs already in operation , which might otherwise result from the allotment of funds on the basis of wealth and population alone . END

explanation of matching formula . END
as is the case with the allotment provisions for support of vocational rehabilitation services , the matching requirements are also based on a statutory formula . END
prior to 1960 , in order to provide matching for the minimum ( base ) allotment , state funds had to equal 1954 state funds . END
prior to and since 1960 the rest of the support allotment is matched at rates related to the fiscal capacity of the state , with a UNK of 40% state ( or UNK federal ) participation in total program costs . END
the percentage of federal participation in such costs for any state is referred to in the law as that state's `` federal share '' . END
for purposes of this explanation , this percentage is referred to as the state's `` unadjusted federal share '' . END
beginning in 1960 , the matching requirements for the base allotment are being adjusted ( upward or downward , as required ) 25% a year , so that by 1963 the entire support allotment will be matched on the basis of a 40% UNK state share , with maximum and minimum state shares of 50% and 30% , respectively . END
the UNK rate of federal participation with respect to any state's base allotment , as well as the adjusted rate in effect during the 1960 - 1962 period , is designated by the statute as that state's `` adjusted federal share '' . END
the provisions for determining a state's unadjusted federal share are designed to reflect the varying financial resources among the states . END
the purpose of the adjusted federal share relating to the base allotment and of the transition provisions for reaching the unadjusted federal share is to prevent UNK from abrupt changes in matching rates . END

important considerations common to each type of shelter are : 1 . END
arrangement of the entrance . END
the entrance must have at least one UNK turn . END
radiation UNK somewhat like light . END
some will go around a corner . END
the rest continues in a straight line . END
therefore , sharp turns in a shelter entrance will reduce radiation intensity inside the shelter . END
ventilation is provided in a concrete block basement shelter by vents in the wall and by the open entrance . END
a blower may be installed to increase comfort . END

lighting is an important consideration . END

a flashlight or electric lantern also should be available for those periods when a brighter light is needed . END
there should be a regular electrical outlet in the shelter as power may continue in many areas . END

if an attack finds you without a prepared shelter END
few areas , if any , are as good as prepared shelters but they are worth knowing about . END
a family dwelling without a basement provides some natural shielding from fallout radiation . END
on the ground floor the radiation would be about half what it is outside . END
the best protection would be on the ground floor in the central part of the house . END
a UNK basement can cut the fallout radiation to one-tenth of the outside level . END
the safest place is the basement corner least exposed to windows and deepest below ground . END
if there is time after the warning , the basement shielding could be improved substantially by UNK windows with bricks , dirt , books , magazines , or other heavy material . END
large apartment buildings of masonry or concrete provide better natural shelter than the usual family dwellings . END
in general , such apartments afford more protection than smaller buildings because their walls are thick and there is more space . END
the central area of the ground floor of a heavily constructed apartment building , with concrete floors , should provide more fallout protection than the ordinary basement of a family dwelling . END
the basement of such an apartment building may provide as much natural protection as the specially constructed concrete block shelter recommended for the basement of a family dwelling . END

END

the purpose of this provision was thus explained in the court's opinion : `` END
section 7 is designed to arrest in its UNK not only the substantial lessening of competition from the acquisition by one corporation of the whole or any part of the stock of a competing corporation , but also to arrest in their UNK restraints or monopolies in a relevant market which , as a reasonable probability , appear at the time of suit likely to result from the acquisition by one corporation of all or any part of the stock of any other corporation . END
the section is violated whether or not actual restraints or monopolies , or the substantial lessening of competition , have occurred or are intended . END

foreign policy in its total context END
with this enlarged role in mind , i should like to make a few suggestions : what we in the united states do or do not do will make a very large difference in what happens in the rest of the world . END
we in this department must think about foreign policy in its total context . END
we cannot regard foreign policy as something left over after defense policy or trade policy or fiscal policy has been extracted . END
foreign policy is the total involvement of the american people with peoples and governments abroad . END
that means that , if we are to achieve a new standard of leadership , we must think in terms of the total context of our situation . END
it is the concern of the department of state that the american people are safe and secure -- defense is not a monopoly concern of the department of defense . END
it is also the concern of the department of state that our trading relationships with the rest of the world are vigorous , profitable , and active -- this is not just a passing interest or a matter of concern only to the department of commerce . END
we can no longer rely on UNK machinery `` somewhere upstairs '' to resolve differences between this and other departments . END
assistant secretaries of state will now carry an increased burden of active formulation and coordination of policies . END
means must be found to enable us to keep in touch as regularly and as efficiently as possible with our colleagues in other departments concerned with foreign policy . END
i think we need to concern ourselves also with the UNK of action . END
every policy officer cannot help but be a planning officer . END
unless we keep our eyes on the horizon ahead , we shall fail to bring ourselves on target with the present . END
the movement of events is so fast , the pace so severe , that an attempt to peer into the future is essential if we are to think accurately about the present . END
if there is anything which we can do in the executive branch of the government to speed up the processes by which we come to decisions on matters on which we must act promptly , that in itself would be a major contribution to the conduct of our affairs . END
action taken today is often far more valuable than action taken several months later in response to a situation then out of control . END
there will of course be times for delay and inaction . END
what i am suggesting is that when we delay , or when we fail to act , we do so intentionally and not through UNK or through UNK or procedural difficulties . END
i also hope that we can do something about reducing the infant mortality rate of ideas -- an UNK of all UNK . END
we want to stimulate ideas from the bottom to the top of the department . END
we want to make sure that our junior colleagues realize that ideas are welcome , that initiative goes right down to the bottom and goes all the way to the top . END
i hope no one expects that only presidential appointees are looked upon as sources of ideas . END
the responsibility for taking the initiative in generating ideas is that of every officer in the department who has a policy function , regardless of rank . END
further , i would hope that we could pay attention to little things . END
while observing the operations of our government in various parts of the world , i have felt that in many situations where our policies were good we have tended to ignore minor problems which spoiled our main effort . END
to cite only a few examples : the wrong man in the wrong position , perhaps even in a junior position abroad , can be a source of great harm to our policy ; ; END
the attitudes of a u.n. delegate who experiences difficulty in finding adequate housing in new york city , or of a foreign diplomat in similar circumstances in our capital , can easily be directed against the united states and all that it stands for . END
dozens of seemingly small matters go wrong all over the world . END
sometimes those who know about them are too far down the line to be able to do anything about them . END
i would hope that we could create the recognition in the department and overseas that those who come across little things going wrong have the responsibility for bringing these to the attention of those who can do something about them . END
if the department of state is to take primary responsibility for foreign policy in washington , it follows that the ambassador is expected to take charge overseas . END
this does not mean in a purely UNK sense but in an active , operational , interested , responsible fashion . END
he is expected to know about what is going on among the representatives of other agencies who are stationed in his country . END
he is expected to supervise , to encourage , to direct , to assist in any way he can . END
if any official operation abroad begins to go wrong , we shall look to the ambassador to find out why and to get suggestions for UNK action . END
the problems of a policy officer END
it occurred to me that you might be interested in some thoughts which i expressed privately in recent years , in the hope of clearing up a certain confusion in the public mind about what foreign policy is all about and what it means , and of developing a certain compassion for those who are carrying such responsibilities inside government . END
i tried to do so by calling to their attention some of the problems that a senior UNK policy officer faces . END
this means practically everybody in this room . END
whether it will strike home for you or not will be for you to determine . END
the senior policy officer may be moved to think hard about a problem by any of an infinite variety of stimuli : an idea in his own head , the suggestions of a colleague , a question from the secretary or the president , a proposal by another department , a communication from a foreign government or an american ambassador abroad , the filing of an item for the agenda of the united nations or of any other of dozens of international bodies , a news item read at the breakfast table , a question to the president or the secretary at a news conference , a speech by a senator or congressman , an article in a periodical , a resolution from a national organization , a request for assistance from some private american interests abroad , et cetera , ad UNK . END
the policy officer lives with his UNK UNK for the questions which fall within his range of responsibility . END
his first thought is about the question itself : is there a question here for american foreign policy , and , if so , what is it ? ? END
for he knows that the first and sometimes most difficult job is to know what the question is -- that when it is accurately identified it sometimes answers itself , and that the way in which it is posed frequently shapes the answer . END
chewing it over with his colleagues and in his own mind , he reaches a tentative identification of the question -- tentative because it may change as he UNK it further and because , if no UNK answer can be found , it may have to be changed into one which can be answered . END
meanwhile he has been thinking about the facts surrounding the problem , facts which he knows can never be complete , and the general background , much of which has already been lost to history . END
he is UNK of the expert help available to him and draws these resources into play , taking care to examine at least some of the raw material which UNK their frequently UNK conclusions . END
he knows that he must give the expert his place , but he knows that he must also keep him in it . END
he is already beginning to box the compass of alternative lines of action , including doing nothing . END
he knows that he is thinking about action in relation to a future which can be perceived but dimly through a UNK fog . END
but he takes his bearings from the great UNK of policy , UNK UNK , the commitments of the united states under international charters and treaties , basic statutes , and UNK notions of the american people about how we are to conduct ourselves , in policy literature such as country papers and national security council papers accumulated in the department . END
he will not be surprised to find that general principles produce conflicting results in the factual situation with which he is confronted . END
he must think about which of these principles must take UNK . END
he will know that general policy papers written months before may not fit his problem because of crucial changes in circumstance . END
he is aware that every moderately important problem UNK UNK into every other problem . END
he must deal with the question of how to manage a part when it cannot be handled without relation to the whole -- when the whole is too large to grasp . END
he must think of others who have a stake in the question and in its answer . END
who should be consulted among his colleagues in the department or other departments and agencies of the government ? ? END
which american ambassadors could provide helpful advice ? ? END
are private interests sufficiently involved to be consulted ? ? END
what is the probable attitude of other governments , including those less directly involved ? ? END
how and at what stage and in what sequence are other governments to be consulted ? ? END
if action is indicated , what kind of action is relevant to the problem ? ? END
the selection of the wrong tools can mean waste , at best , and at worst an unwanted UNK of the problem itself . END
can the president or the secretary act under existing authority , or will new legislation and new money be required ? ? END
should the action be UNK or UNK ? ? END
is the matter one for the united nations or some other international body ? ? END
for , if so , the path leads through a complex process of parliamentary diplomacy which adds still another dimension to the problem . END
respect for the opinions of mankind END
what type of action can hope to win public support , first in this country and then abroad ? ? END
for the policy officer will know that action can almost never be secret and that in general the effectiveness of policy will be conditioned by the readiness of the country to sustain it . END
he is interested in public opinion for two reasons : first , because it is important in itself , and , second , because he knows that the american public cares about a decent respect for the opinions of mankind . END
and , given probable public attitudes -- about which reasonably good estimates can be made -- what action is called for to insure necessary support ? ? END
may i add a caution on this particular point ? ? END
we do not want policy officers below the level of presidential appointees to concern themselves too much with problems of domestic politics in recommending foreign policy action . END
in the first place our business is foreign policy , and it is the business of the presidential leadership and his appointees in the department to consider the domestic political aspects of a problem . END
mr. truman emphasized this point by saying , `` you fellows in the department of state don't know much about domestic politics '' . END
this is an important consideration . END
if we sit here reading editorials and looking at UNK polls and other reports that cross our desks , we should realize that this is raw , UNK opinion expressed in the absence of leadership . END
what the american people will do turns in large degree on their leadership . END
we cannot test public opinion until the president and the leaders of the country have gone to the public to explain what is required and have asked them for support for the necessary action . END
i doubt , for example , that , 3 months before the leadership began to talk about what came to be the marshall plan , any UNK expert would have said that the country would have accepted such proposals . END
the problem in the policy officer's mind thus begins to take shape as a UNK of utterly complicated factors -- political , military , economic , financial , legal , legislative , procedural , administrative -- to be sorted out and handled within a political system which moves by consent in relation to an external environment which cannot be under control . END
and the policy officer has the UNK of time snapping at his heels . END
while there should be no general age limit or restriction to one sex , there will be particular projects requiring special maturity and some open only to men or to women . END
the peace corps should not pay the expenses of a wife or family , unless the wife is also accepted for full-time peace corps work on the same project . END
there should be no draft exemption because of peace corps service . END
in most cases service in the corps will probably be considered a ground for temporary UNK . END
peace corps volunteers obviously should not be paid what they might earn in comparable activities in the united states . END
nor would it be possible in many cases for them to live in health or any effectiveness on what their counterparts abroad are paid . END
the guiding principle indeed should not be anything like compensation for individual services . END
rather the principle should be akin to that of the allowance . END
peace corps volunteers should be given just enough to provide a minimum decent standard of living . END
they should live in modest circumstances , avoiding all conspicuous consumption . END
wherever possible they should live with their host country counterparts . END
some special health requirements might have to be met . END
for example , it probably will be necessary for the corps to have authority to pay medical expenses of volunteers . END
perhaps existing public health service , state department and armed services medical facilities can be utilized . END
for UNK to the u.s. , volunteers should be given some separation allowance at the end of their overseas service , based on the length of time served . END
in what part of the government should the peace corps be established ? ? END
the idea of a peace corps has captured the imagination of a great many people . END
support for it cuts across party , regional , ethnic and other lines . END
the peace corps , therefore , offers an opportunity to add a new dimension to our approach to the world -- an opportunity for the american people to think anew and start UNK in their participation in world development . END
for this , the peace corps should be administered by a small , new , alive agency operating as one component in our whole overseas operation . END
pending the reorganization of our foreign aid structure and program , the peace corps should be established as an agency in the department of state . END
when the aid operations are reorganized the peace corps should remain a UNK , functional unit . END
meanwhile , the peace corps could be physically located in UNK facilities and depend on the state department and UNK for administrative support and , when needed , program assistance . END
in this way the peace corps can be launched with its own identity and spirit and yet receive the necessary assistance from those now responsible for united states foreign policy and our overseas operations . END
how and when should the peace corps be launched ? ? END
the peace corps can either begin in very low gear , with only preparatory work undertaken between now and when congress finally UNK special funds for it -- or it can be launched now and in earnest by executive action , with sufficient funds and made available from existing mutual security appropriations to permit a number of substantial projects to start this summer . END
the peace corps should be launched soon so that the opportunity to recruit the most qualified people from this year's graduating classes will not be lost . END
nor should we lose the opportunity to use this summer for training on university UNK . END
if launched in a careful but determined way within the next few weeks , the peace corps could have several hundred persons in training this summer for placement next fall . END
within a year or two several thousand might be in service . END
it can then grow steadily as it proves itself and as the need for it is demonstrated . END
what would the first projects be ? ? END
in the first year there should probably be considerable emphasis on teaching projects . END
the need here is most clearly felt and our capacity to recruit and train qualified volunteers in a short period of time is greatest . END
there would , however , be a variety of other skills -- medical , agricultural , engineering -- which would be called for in the first year through the private agency programs and through the provision of technician UNK to existing development projects . END
the first year's projects should also be spread through several countries in latin america , africa and asia . END
how will the peace corps be received abroad ? ? END
although the need for outside trained manpower exists in every newly developing nation , the readiness to receive such manpower , or to receive it from the united states will vary from country to country . END
a certain skepticism about the coming of americans is to be expected in many quarters . END
unfriendly political groups will no doubt do everything in their power to promote active hostility . END
but there are indications that many developing nations will welcome peace corps volunteers , and that if the volunteers are well chosen , they will soon demonstrate their value and make many friends . END
it is important , however , that the peace corps be advanced not as an arm of the cold war but as a contribution to the world community . END
in presenting it to other governments and to the united nations , we could propose that every nation consider the formation of its own peace corps and that the united nations sponsor the idea and form an international coordinating committee . END
we should hope that peace corps projects will be truly international and that our citizens will find themselves working alongside citizens of the host country and also volunteers from other lands . END
in any case , our peace corps personnel should be offered as technician UNK in development projects of the u.n. and other international agencies . END
the peace corps is not a diplomatic or propaganda venture but a genuine experiment in international partnership . END
our aim must be to learn as much as we teach . END
the peace corps offers an opportunity to bring home to the united states the problems of the world as well as an opportunity to meet urgent host country needs for trained manpower . END
if presented in this spirit , the response and the results will be UNK better . END
how will it be financed ? ? END
the already appropriated funds within the discretion of the president and secretary of state under the mutual security act are the only immediately available source of financing this summer's pilot programs of the peace corps . END
if it is decided to make a small shift which may be required from military aid or special assistance funds , in order to carry out the purposes of the mutual security act through this new peaceful program , this will be a hopeful sign to the world . END
congress should then be asked to give the peace corps a firm legislative foundation for the next fiscal year . END
specifically , congress should consider authorizing the peace corps to receive contributions from american businesses , unions , civic organizations and the public at large . END
for this must be the project of the whole american people . END
an advisory council of outstanding public figures with experience in world affairs should be formed to give the program continuing guidance and to afford a focal point for public understanding . END
steps should also be taken to link the food for peace program with the peace corps , so that foreign UNK accumulated by the sale of u.s. surplus food under UNK UNK can be put to use to pay some of the host country expenses of peace corps personnel . END
the extent to which participating bodies such as u. s. voluntary agencies , universities , international organizations , and the host country or institutions in the host country can and should share the cost of the peace corps programs must be fully explored . END
is it worth the cost and the risks ? ? END
no matter how well conceived and efficiently run , there probably will be failures . END
these could be costly and have a serious effect both at home and abroad . END
but as the popular response suggests , the UNK of the peace corps is very great . END
it can contribute to the development of critical countries and regions . END
it can promote international cooperation and good will toward this country . END
it can also contribute to the education of america and to more intelligent american participation in the world . END
with thousands of young americans going to work in developing areas , millions of americans will become more directly involved in the world than ever before . END
with colleges and universities carrying a large part of the program , and with students looking toward peace corps service , there will be an impact on educational curriculum and student seriousness . END
the letters home , the talks later given by returning members of the peace corps , the influence on the lives of those who spend two or three years in hard work abroad -- all this may combine to provide a substantial popular base for responsible american policies toward the world . END
and this is meeting the world's need , too , since what the world most needs from this country is better understanding of the world . END
the peace corps thus can add a new dimension to america's world policy -- one for which people here and abroad have long been waiting . END

to the congress of the united states : END
i recommend to the congress the establishment of a permanent peace corps -- a pool of trained american men and women sent overseas by the u.s. government or through private organizations and institutions to help foreign countries meet their urgent needs for skilled manpower . END
i have today signed an executive order establishing a peace corps on a temporary pilot basis . END
the temporary peace corps will be a source of information and experience to aid us in formulating more effective plans for a permanent organization . END
in addition , by starting the peace corps now we will be able to begin training young men and women for overseas duty this summer with the objective of placing them in overseas positions by late fall . END
this temporary peace corps is being established under existing authority in the mutual security act and will be located in the department of state . END
its initial expenses will be paid from appropriations currently available for our foreign aid program . END
throughout the world the people of the newly developing nations are struggling for economic and social progress which reflects their deepest desires . END
our own freedom , and the future of freedom around the world , depend , in a very real sense , on their ability to build growing and independent nations where men can live in dignity , liberated from the bonds of hunger , ignorance and poverty . END
one of the greatest obstacles to the achievement of this goal is the lack of trained men and women with the skill to teach the young and assist in the operation of development projects -- men and women with the capacity to cope with the demands of swiftly UNK economics , and with the dedication to put that capacity to work in the villages , the mountains , the towns and the factories of dozens of struggling nations . END
the vast task of economic development urgently requires skilled people to do the work of the society -- to help teach in the schools , construct development projects , demonstrate modern methods of sanitation in the villages , and perform a hundred other tasks calling for training and advanced knowledge . END
to meet this urgent need for skilled manpower we are proposing the establishment of a peace corps -- an organization which will recruit and train american volunteers , sending them abroad to work with the people of other nations . END
this organization will differ from existing assistance programs in that its members will supplement technical advisers by offering the specific skills needed by developing nations if they are to put technical advice to work . END
they will help provide the skilled manpower necessary to carry out the development projects planned by the host governments , acting at a working level and serving at great personal sacrifice . END
there is little doubt that the number of those who wish to serve will be far greater than our capacity to absorb them . END

this broad delegation leaves within our discretion ( subject to the UNK criterion of the public interest ) both the determination of what degree of interference shall be considered excessive , and the methods by which such excessive interference shall be avoided . END
the present proceeding is concerned with the standard broadcast ( am ) band , from UNK UNK to UNK UNK . END
whenever two or more standard broadcast stations operate simultaneously on the same or closely adjacent frequencies , each UNK to some extent with reception of the other . END
the extent of such interference -- which may be so slight as to be UNK at any point where either of the stations UNK a usable signal , or may be so great as to virtually destroy the service areas of both stations -- depends on many factors , among the principal ones being the distance between the stations , their respective radiated power , and , of particular significance here , the time of day . END
other factors playing a part in the extent of am service and interference are the frequency involved , the time of year , the position of the year in the UNK cycle , ground conductivity along the transmission path , atmospheric and UNK noise , and others . END
with the existence of these many factors , some of them variable , it obviously has never been and is not now possible for the commission to make assignments of am stations on a UNK basis which will insure against any interference in any circumstances . END
rather , such assignments are made , as they must be , on the basis of certain overall rules and standards , representing to some extent a statistical approach to the problem , taking into account for each situation some of the variables ( e.g. , power and station UNK ) and averaging out others in order to achieve the balance which must be struck between protection against destructive interference and the assignment of a number of stations large enough to afford optimum radio service to the nation . END
an example of the overall standards applied is the UNK ratio established for the determination of that degree of cochannel interference which is regarded as UNK . END
by this standard , it is determined that where two stations operating on the same frequency are involved , UNK interference from station a exists at any point within the service area of station b where station a's signal is of an intensity UNK or more of the strength of station UNK signal at that point . END
the UNK ratio for cochannel interference UNK one of the fundamental limiting principles which we must always take into account in am assignments and UNK -- that signals from a particular station are potential sources of UNK interference over an area much greater than that within which they provide useful service . END
a second fundamental principle is that involved particularly in the present proceeding -- the difference between nighttime and daytime propagation conditions with respect to the standard broadcast frequencies . END
this is a phenomenon familiar to all radio listeners , resulting from reflection of skywave signals at night from the UNK layer in the upper atmosphere known as the UNK . END
all am stations UNK both skywave and groundwave signals , at all hours ; ; END
but during the middle daytime hours these skywave UNK are not reflected in any substantial quantity , and during this portion of the day both skywave service and skywave interference are , in general , negligible . END
but during nighttime hours the skywave UNK are reflected from the UNK , thereby creating the possibility of one station's rendering service , via skywave , at a much greater distance than it can through its groundwave signal , and at the same time vastly UNK the interference problem because of the still greater distance over which these skywave signals may cause interference to the signals of stations on the same and closely adjacent frequencies . END
because of the difference between daytime and nighttime propagation conditions , it has been necessary to evolve different allocation structures for daytime and nighttime broadcasting in the am band , with many more stations operating during the day than at night . END
it was recognized years ago that the transition from daytime to nighttime propagation conditions , and vice versa , is not an instantaneous process , but takes place over periods of time from roughly 2 hours before sunset until about 2 hours after sunset , and again from roughly 2 hours before sunrise until some 2 hours after sunrise . END
during the period of about 4 hours around sunset , skywave transmission conditions are building up until full nighttime conditions prevail ; ; END
during the same period around sunrise , skywave transmission is declining , until at about 2 hours after sunrise it reaches a point where it becomes of little practical significance . END
however , in this case as elsewhere it was necessary to arrive at a single standard to be applied to all situations , representing an averaging of conditions , and thus to fix particular points in time which would be considered the dividing points between daytime and nighttime conditions . END
it was determined that the hours of sunrise and sunset , respectively , should be used for this purpose . END
accordingly , the UNK rules adopted these hours as limitations upon the operation of daytime stations . END
class 2 , stations operating on clear channels are required to cease operation or operate under nighttime restrictions beginning either at local sunset ( for daytime class 2 , stations ) or sunset at the location of the dominant class 1 , station where located west of the class 2 , station ( for UNK class 2 , stations ) . END
the same restrictions apply after local sunset in the case of class 3 , stations operating on regional channels , which after that time are required to operate under nighttime restrictions in order to protect each other . END
with respect to nighttime assignments , the degree of skywave service and interference is determined by skywave curves ( figs. 1 and 2 of UNK UNK of the rules ) giving average skywave values . END
these curves were derived by an analysis of extensive skywave measurement data . END
it was recognized that skywave signals , because of their reflected nature , are of great UNK and subject to wide UNK in strength . END
for this reason , the more uncertain skywave service was UNK `` secondary '' in our rules , as compared to the UNK , more reliable groundwave `` primary service '' , and , for both skywave service and skywave interference , signal strength is expressed in terms of percentage of time a particular UNK level is exceeded -- 50 percent of the time for skywave service , 10 percent of the time for skywave interference . END
as mentioned , the allocation of am stations represents a balance between protection against interference and the provision of opportunity for an adequate number of stations . END
the rules and policies to be applied in this process of course must be based on objectives which represent what is to be desired if radio service is to be of maximum use to the nation . END
our objectives , as we have stated many times , are -- ( 1 ) END
to provide some service to all listeners ; ; END
to provide as many choices of service to as many listeners as possible ; ; END
to provide service of local origin to as many listeners as possible . END
since broadcast frequencies are very limited in number , these objectives are to some extent inconsistent in that not all of them can be fully realized , and to the extent that each is realized , there is a corresponding reduction of the possibilities for fullest achievement of the others . END
accordingly , the commission has recognized that an optimum allocation pattern for one frequency does not necessarily represent the best pattern for other frequencies , and has assigned different frequencies for use by different classes of stations . END
some 45 frequencies are assigned for use primarily by dominant class 1 , -- a or class 1 , -- b UNK stations , designed to operate with adequate power and to provide service -- both groundwave and ( at night ) skywave -- over large areas and at great distances , being protected against interference to the degree necessary to achieve this objective . END
in dealing with these frequencies , the objective listed first above -- provision of service to all listeners -- was UNK ; ; END
the other objectives were subordinated to it . END
the class 1 , stations on these clear channels are protected to their UNK groundwave contours against daytime cochannel interference . END
with respect to skywave service rendered at night , class 1 , -- a stations are the only stations permitted to operate in the united states on clear channels specified for class 1 , -- a operation , and so render skywave service free from cochannel interference UNK they may be received ; ; END
class 1 , -- b stations are protected at night to their UNK UNK time skywave contours against cochannel interference . END
since the provision of skywave service requires adequate freedom from interference , only class 1 , stations are capable of rendering skywave service . END
but nighttime operation by stations of other classes of course entails skywave interference to groundwave service , interference which is substantial unless steps are taken to minimize it . END
with respect to other frequencies , these are designated as regional or local , and assigned for use by class 3 , and class 4 , stations , respectively , stations operating generally with lower power . END
in the allocation pattern worked out for these frequencies , the provision of long-range service has to some extent been subordinated to the other two objectives -- assignment of multiple facilities , and assignment of stations in as many communities as possible . END
as mentioned , the primary allocation objective to be followed in the allocation of stations on clear channels is the provision of widespread service , free from destructive interference . END
during nighttime hours , because of the intense skywave propagation then prevailing , no large number of stations can be permitted to operate on one of these channels , if the wide area service for which these frequencies are assigned is to be rendered satisfactorily by the dominant stations which must be relied upon to render it . END
therefore , under our UNK allocation rules , on some of these channels no station other than the dominant ( class 1 ) -- a ) station is permitted to operate at night , so that the 1 , -- a station can render service , interference free , wherever it can be received . END
on the remainder of the clear channels , the dominant ( class 1 ) -- b stations are protected as described above , and the relatively small number of secondary ( class 2 ) ) stations permitted to operate on these channels at night are required to operate UNK and/or with reduced power so as to protect the class 1 , stations . END
in the daytime , on the other hand , since skywave transmission is relatively inefficient , it is possible to assign a substantially larger number of stations on these channels . END
additional class 2 , assignments for daytime operation can be made without causing destructive interference to the class 1 , stations or to each other , and by their operation provide additional service on these channels and additional local outlets for a large number of communities . END
such additional daytime class 2 , assignments are appropriate if optimum use is to be made of these frequencies , and the commission has over the years made a large number of them . END
similarly , on the regional channels many class 3 , stations have been assigned either to operate daytime only or to operate nighttime with directional UNK and/or lower power . END
essentially , the question presented for decision in the present daytime skywave proceeding is whether our decision ( in UNK ) to assign stations on the basis of daytime conditions from sunrise to sunset , is sound as a basis for am UNK , or whether , in the light of later developments and new understanding , skywave transmission is of such significance during the hours immediately before sunset and after sunrise that this condition should be taken into account , and some stations required to afford protection to other stations during these hours . END

the decision reached in UNK was made after the accumulation of a large amount of data and thorough study thereof . END
since then , there has been a notable increase in the number of stations and also the accumulation of additional data and the development of new techniques for using it , leading to a better understanding of propagation phenomena . END

the greater the range of choice , the greater the rate of change . END
for change is dependent on the possibilities that individual men glimpse for the future . END

the eternal truth is that progress -- due , as it always is , to individual creative genius -- is just as dependent on freedom as human life is dependent on the beating of the heart . END

the basic market for textiles is growing with the expansion of the population that began 20 years ago . END
another growth factor is increased consumer demand for better quality and larger quantities of fabrics that go with a rising standard of living . END
as in many other industries , rising costs and intense competition , both domestic and foreign , have exerted increasing pressure on earnings of the textile industry in recent years . END
in textiles , as elsewhere , a major part of the solution lies in greater efficiency and higher productivity . END

how well do faculty members govern themselves ? ? END

it has recently become practical to use the radio emission of the moon and planets as a new source of information about these bodies and their atmospheres . END
the results of present observations of the thermal radio emission of the moon are consistent with the very low thermal conductivity of the surface layer which was derived from the variation in the infrared emission during eclipses ( e.g. , UNK , 1958 ) . END
when sufficiently accurate and complete measurements are available , it will be possible to set limits on the thermal and electrical characteristics of the surface and UNK materials of the moon . END
observations of the radio emission of a planet which has an extensive atmosphere will probe the atmosphere to a greater extent than those using shorter wave lengths and should in some cases give otherwise UNK information about the characteristics of the solid surface . END
radio observations of venus and jupiter have already supplied unexpected experimental data on the physical conditions of these planets . END
the observed intensity of the radio emission of venus is much higher than the expected thermal intensity , although the spectrum indicated by measurements at wave lengths near 3 cm and 10 cm is like that of a black body at about UNK . END
this result suggests a very high temperature at the solid surface of the planet , although there is the possibility that the observed radiation may be a combination of both thermal and UNK components and that the observed spectrum is that of a black body merely by coincidence . END
for the case of jupiter , the radio emission spectrum is definitely not like the spectrum of a black-body radiator , and it seems very likely that the radiation reaching the earth is a combination of thermal radiation from the atmosphere and UNK components . END
of the remaining planets , only mars and UNK have been observed as radio sources , and not very much information is available . END
mars has been observed twice at about UNK wave length , and the intensity of the observed radiation is in reasonable agreement with the thermal radiation which might be predicted on the basis of the known temperature of mars . END
the low intensity of the radiation from UNK has limited observations , but again the measured radiation seems to be consistent with a thermal origin . END
no attempts to measure the radio emission of the remaining planets have been reported , and , because of their distances , small diameters , or low temperatures , the thermal radiation at radio wave lengths reaching the earth from these sources is expected to be of very low intensity . END
in spite of this , the very large radio UNK and improved UNK techniques which are now becoming available should make it possible to observe the radio emission of most of the planets in a few years . END
the study of the radio emission of the moon and planets began with the detection of the thermal radiation of the moon at UNK wave length by UNK and UNK ( 1946 ) . END
this was followed by a comprehensive series of observations of the UNK emission of the moon over three lunar cycles by UNK and UNK ( 1949 ) . END
they deduced from their measurements that the radio emission from the whole disk of the moon varied during a UNK in a roughly UNK fashion ; ; END
that the amplitude of the variation was considerably less than the amplitude of the variation in the infrared emission as measured by UNK and UNK ( 1930 ) and UNK ( 1935 ) ; ; END
and that the maximum of the radio emission came about UNK days after full moon , which is again in contrast to the infrared emission , which reaches its maximum at full moon . END
UNK and UNK explained their observations by pointing out that UNK materials which are likely to make up the surface of the moon would be partially transparent to radio waves , although opaque to infrared radiation . END
the infrared emission could then be assumed to originate at the surface of the moon , while the radio emission UNK at some depth beneath the surface , where the temperature variation due to solar radiation is reduced in amplitude and shifted in phase . END
since the absorption of radio waves in UNK material varies with wave length , it should be possible to sample the temperature variation at different depths beneath the surface and possibly detect changes in the structure or composition of the lunar surface material . END
the radio emission of a planet was first detected in 1955 , when burke and franklin ( 1955 ) identified the origin of UNK radio noise on their records at about 15 meters wave length as emission from jupiter . END

the UNK characteristics of planetary radio radiation are the intensity , the polarization , and the direction of arrival of the waves . END
the maximum angular diameter of any planetary disk as observed from the earth is about 1 minute of arc . END
this is much smaller than the highest resolution of even the very large UNK now under construction , and consequently the radio emission of different regions of the disk cannot be resolved . END

the concept of apparent black-body temperature is used to describe the radiation received from the moon and the planets . END
the received radiation is compared with the radiation from a hypothetical black body which UNK the same solid angle as the visible disk of the planet . END
the apparent black-body disk temperature is the temperature which must be assumed for the black body in order that the intensity of its radiation should equal that of the observed radiation . END
the use of this concept does not specify the origin of the radiation , and only if the planet really UNK as a black body , will the apparent black-body temperature correspond to the physical temperature of the UNK material . END
the radio radiation of the sun which is reflected from the moon and planets should be negligible compared with their thermal emission at UNK wave lengths , except possibly at times of exceptional outbursts of solar radio noise . END
the UNK level of UNK UNK solar radiation would increase the average disk brightness temperature by less than UNK . END

experiments were made on an electric arc applying a porous graphite anode cooled by a transpiring gas ( argon ) . END
thus , the energy transferred from the arc to the anode was partly fed back into the arc . END
it was shown that by proper anode design the net energy loss of the arc to the anode could be reduced to approximately 15% of the total arc energy . END
a detailed energy balance of the anode was established . END
the anode UNK could be reduced to a negligible amount . END
the dependence of the arc voltage upon the mass flow velocity of the UNK gas was investigated for various arc lengths and currents between 100 UNK and 200 aj . END
qualitative observations were made and high-speed motion pictures were taken to study flow phenomena in the arc at various mass flow velocities . END
the high heat fluxes existing at the electrode surfaces of electric arcs necessitate extensive cooling to prevent electrode UNK . END
the cooling requirements are particularly severe at the anode . END
in UNK electric arcs , for instance , approximately 90% of the total arc power is transferred to the anode giving rise to local heat fluxes in excess of af as measured by the authors -- the exact value depending on the arc atmosphere . END
in plasma generators as currently commercially available for industrial use or as high temperature research tools often more than 50% of the total energy input is being transferred to the cooling medium of the anode . END
the higher heat transfer rates at the anode compared with those at the cathode can be explained by the physical phenomena occurring in free burning arcs . END
in plasma generators the superimposed forced UNK may modify the picture somewhat . END
the heat transfer to the anode is due to the following effects : 1 . END
heat of condensation ( work function ) plus kinetic energy of the electrons impinging on the anode . END
this energy transfer depends on the current , the temperature in the arc column , the anode material , and the conditions in the anode sheath . END
heat transfer by molecular UNK as well as by radiation from the arc column . END
the heat transfer to the anode in free burning arcs is enhanced by a hot gas jet flowing from the cathode towards the anode with velocities up af . END
this phenomenon has been experimentally investigated in detail by UNK ( ref. 1 ) . END
the pressure gradient producing the jet is due to the nature of the magnetic field in the arc ( rapid decrease of current density from cathode to the anode ) . END
hence , the flow conditions at the anode of free burning arcs resemble those near a UNK point . END
it is apparent from the above and from experimental evidence that the cooling requirements for the anode of free burning arcs are large compared with those for the cathode . END
the gas flow through a plasma generator will modify these conditions ; ; END
however , the anode is still the part receiving the largest heat flux . END
an attempt to improve the life of the UNK or the efficiency of the plasma generators must , therefore , aim at a reduction of the anode loss . END
the following possibilities exist for achieving this : 1 . END
the use of high voltages and low currents by proper design to reduce electron heat transfer to the anode for a given power output . END
continuous motion of the arc contact area at the anode by flow or magnetic forces . END
feedback of the energy transferred to the anode by applying gas transpiration through the anode . END
the third method was , to our knowledge , successfully applied for the first time by c. sheer and UNK ( ref. 2 ) . END
the purpose of the present study is to study the thermal conditions and to establish an energy balance for a transpiration cooled anode as well as the effect of blowing on the arc voltage . END
gas injection through a porous anode ( transpiration cooling ) not only feeds back the energy transferred to the anode by the above mentioned processes , but also UNK the conditions in the arc itself . END
a detailed study of this latter phenomenon was not attempted in this paper . END
argon was used as a blowing gas to exclude any effects of dissociation or chemical reaction . END
the anode material was porous graphite . END
UNK porous metals should be usable in principle . END
however , technical difficulties arise by melting at local hot spots . END
