some of the features of the top portions of figure 1 and figure 2 were mentioned in discussing table 1 . END
first , the onset profile spreads across approximately 12 years for boys and 10 years for girls . END
in contrast , 20 of the 21 lines in the completion profile ( excluding center 5 for boys and 4 for girls ) are bunched and extend over a much shorter period , approximately 30 months for boys and 40 months for girls . END
the maturity chart for each sex demonstrates clearly that onset is a phenomenon of infancy and early childhood whereas completion is a phenomenon of the later portion of adolescence . END
second , for both sexes , the 21 transverse lines in the onset profile vary more in individual spread than those in the completion profile . END
although the standard deviation values on which spread of the lines is based are relatively larger for those centers which begin to UNK early ( table 1 ) , there are considerable differences in this value between centers having the closely timed onsets . END
third , the process of UNK is seen to begin later and to continue much longer for these boys than for the girls , a fact which UNK data for other groups of children . END
the onset profile and completion profile are constructed to serve as norms for children . END
it is convenient to classify a child's onset ages and completion ages as `` advanced '' , `` moderate '' ( UNK ) , or `` delayed '' according to whether the child's age equivalent `` dots '' appeared to the left of , upon , or to the right of the appropriate short transverse line . END
when a dot appears close to the end of the transverse line , the `` moderate '' rating may be further classified according to the position of the dot with respect to the vertical marking denoting the mean age . END
such classifications may be called `` somewhat advanced '' or `` somewhat delayed '' , as the case may be , reserving `` moderate '' for dots upon or close to the mean . END
in the lower portion of each chart , the skeletal age ( hand ) of boy 34 and girl 2 may be similarly classified . END
there the middle one of the three curves denotes `` mean skeletal age '' for the maturity series boys and girls . END
the upper curve denotes the mean plus one standard deviation , and the lower curve represents the mean minus one standard deviation . END
thus , a child's skeletal age `` dots '' may be classified as `` advanced '' when they appear above the middle curve , `` moderate '' when they appear immediately above or below the middle curve , and `` delayed '' when they appear below the lower curve . END
to UNK the purpose of the skeletal maturity chart : each contains two kinds of skeletal maturity norms which show two quite different methods of depicting developmental level of growth centers . END
first , the upper portion requires series of films for every child , consisting of those from hand , elbow , shoulder , knee , and foot . END
the lower portion UNK only films of hand . END
second , the upper portion permits comparison of maturity levels of an equal number of growth centers from the long , short , and round bones of the five regions . END
the lower portion permits comparison of maturity levels of short and round bones predominantly , since only two long bones are included in hand and wrist as a region . END
third , the upper portion deals with only two indicators of developmental level , onset and completion . END
the lower portion utilizes the full complement of intermediate maturity indicators of each hand center as well as their onset and completion . END
fourth , the two indicators are for the most part widely separated UNK , with the extensive age gap occurring during childhood for all but one growth center . END
the lower portion provides a rating at any stage between infancy and UNK . END
onsets , completions , and skeletal ages ( hand ) of boy 34 and girl 2 may be directly compared and classified , using only those skeletal ages which appear immediately below the onset profile and the completion profile . END
it may be assumed that differences in ratings due to selection of growth centers from specific regions of the body will be small , according to existing tables of onset age and completion age for centers throughout the body . END
accordingly , maturity level ratings by means of the upper portion and lower portion of the chart , respectively , should be somewhat similar since skeletal age assessments are dependent upon onsets during infancy and upon completions during adolescence . END
it is clear that there are some differences in the ratings , but there is substantial agreement . END
since a skeletal age rating can be made at any age during growth , from elbow , shoulder , knee , or foot as well as hand , it seems to be the method of choice when one wishes to study most aspects of skeletal developmental progress during childhood . END

some experiments are composed of UNK of independent trials , each with two possible outcomes . END
the binomial probability distribution may describe the variation that occurs from one set of trials of such a binomial experiment to another . END
we devote a chapter to the binomial distribution not only because it is a mathematical model for an enormous variety of real life phenomena , but also because it has important properties that UNK in many other probability models . END
we begin with a few examples of binomial experiments . END
a trained marksman shooting five rounds at a target , all under practically the same conditions , may hit the bull's-eye from 0 to 5 times . END
in repeated sets of five shots his numbers of bull's-eyes vary . END
what can we say of the probabilities of the different possible numbers of bull's-eyes ? ? END
in UNK of eight mice from similar parents , the number of mice with straight instead of UNK hair is an integer from 0 to 8 . END
what probabilities should be attached to these possible outcomes ? ? END
aces ( ones ) with three dice . END
when three dice are tossed repeatedly , what is the probability that the number of aces is 0 ( or 1 , or 2 , or 3 ) ? ? END
more generally , suppose that an experiment consists of a number of independent trials , that each trial results in either a `` success '' or a `` UNK '' ( `` failure '' ) , and that the probability of success remains constant from trial to trial . END

in general , any outcome we choose may be labeled `` success '' . END

we now generalize these ideas for general binomial experiments . END
for an experiment to qualify as a binomial experiment , it must have four properties : ( 1 ) there must be a fixed number of trials , ( 2 ) each trial must result in a `` success '' or a `` failure '' ( a binomial trial ) , ( 3 ) all trials must have identical probabilities of success , ( 4 ) the trials must be independent of each other . END
below we use our earlier examples to describe and illustrate these four properties . END
we also give , for each property , an example where the property is absent . END
the language and UNK introduced are standard throughout the chapter . END

each of the n trials is either a success or a failure . END
`` success '' and `` failure '' are just convenient UNK for the two categories of outcomes when we talk about binomial trials in general . END
these words are more expressive than UNK like `` a '' and `` UNK '' . END
it is natural from the UNK viewpoint to call a bull's-eye a success , but in the mice example it is arbitrary which category corresponds to straight hair in a mouse . END
the word `` binomial '' means `` of two names '' or `` of two terms '' , and both UNK apply in our work : the first to the names of the two outcomes of a binomial trial , and the second to the terms p and af that represent the probabilities of `` success '' and `` failure '' . END

the trials are independent . END

examples where independence fails . END
a family of five plans to go together either to the beach or to the mountains , and a coin is tossed to decide . END
we want to know the number of people going to the mountains . END
when this experiment is viewed as composed of five binomial trials , one for each member of the family , the outcomes of the trials are obviously not independent . END
indeed , the experiment is better viewed as consisting of one binomial trial for the entire family . END
the following is a less extreme example of dependence . END

a binomial experiment consists of af independent binomial trials , all with the same probability af of yielding a success . END

when each number of successes x is paired with its probability of occurrence af , the set of pairs af , is a probability function called a binomial distribution . END
the choice of p and n determines the binomial distribution uniquely , and different choices always produce different distributions ( except when af ; ; END
then the number of successes is always 0 ) . END
the set of all binomial distributions is called the family of binomial distributions , but in general discussions this expression is often shortened to `` the binomial distribution '' , or even `` the binomial '' when the context is clear . END
binomial distributions were treated by james UNK about UNK , and for this reason binomial trials are sometimes called UNK trials . END
each binomial trial of a binomial experiment produces either 0 or 1 success . END
therefore each binomial trial can be thought of as producing a value of a random variable associated with that trial and taking the values 0 and 1 , with probabilities q and p respectively . END
the several trials of a binomial experiment produce a new random variable x , the total number of successes , which is just the sum of the random variables associated with the single trials . END
the marksman gets two bull's-eyes , one on his third shot and one on his fifth . END
the numbers of successes on the five individual shots are , then , 0 , 0 , 1 , 0 , 1 . END

their sum is x , the total number of successes , which in this experiment has the value af . END

these societies can expect to face difficult times . END
as the historic processes of modernization gradually gain momentum , their cohesion will be threatened by divisive forces , the UNK between rulers and subjects , town and country , will widen ; ; END

nevertheless , with foresight and careful planning , some of the more disruptive and dangerous consequences of social change which have troubled other countries passing through this stage can be escaped . END
the united states can help by communicating a genuine concern with the problems these countries face and a readiness to provide technical and other appropriate forms of assistance where possible . END
our central goal should be to provide the greatest positive incentive for these societies to tackle boldly the tasks which they face . END
at the same time , we should recognize that the obstacles to change and the lack of cohesion and stability which characterize these countries may make them particularly prone to diversions and external adventures of all sorts . END
it may seem to some of them that success can be purchased much less dearly by fishing in the murky waters of international politics than by facing up to the UNK tasks at home . END
we should do what we can to discourage this conclusion , both by offering assistance for their domestic needs and by reacting firmly to irresponsible actions on the world scene . END
when necessary , we should make it clear that countries which choose to derive marginal advantages from the cold war or to exploit their potential for UNK the security of the world will not only lose our sympathy but also risk their own prospects for orderly development . END

the initiation of sampling UNK in ruanda-urundi ( 1952 ) and in the congo ( 1955 - 57 ) were major advances . END
we will deal first with the program in the congo though this was put into operation later than the other . END
the radical nature of the innovation in the congo was not emphasized in the official announcements . END
the term UNK UNK , previously used for the supplementary investigations carried out in connection with the administrative UNK , was used for the new investigations . END
however , the differences in procedure are fundamental . END
these are as follows : ( 1 ) field work procedures . END
field operations were transferred from administrative personnel primarily engaged in other tasks to specially trained teams of full-time african investigators ( three teams , each working in two provinces ) . END
these teams carried out the same operations UNK in different areas . END
( 2 ) nature of the sample . END
sample areas in the new investigations were selected strictly by application of the principles of probability theory , so as to be representative of the total population of defined areas within UNK limits . END
in short , scientific sampling was introduced in place of subjective sampling . END
the populations of the various districts , or other major divisions , were UNK by type of community ( rural , urban , mixed ) and , where appropriate , by ethnic affiliation and by type of economy . END
sample units ( villages in rural areas , houses in cities ) were drawn systematically within these UNK . END
( 3 ) size of the sample . END
different sampling ratios were applied under different conditions . END
higher proportions were sampled in urban and mixed communities than in rural areas . END
about 11 percent of the total population was covered in the new investigation , as compared with about 3 percent in the previous inquiries . END
( 4 ) questions and definitions . END
uniform questions , definitions , and procedures were enforced throughout the whole country . END
data were obtained , separately , on three classes of persons : ( a ) residents , present ; ; END
( b ) residents , absent ; ; END
and ( c ) visitors . END
in the reports , summary results are given for both the de facto ( a and c ) and de UNK ( a and b ) populations ; ; END
but the subsequent analysis of characteristics is reported only for the de UNK population ( or , in some districts , only the de facto population ) . END
these changes represent , in effect , a shift from ( 1 ) an administrative compilation of data obtained through procedures designed primarily to serve political and economic objectives to ( 2 ) a systematic sampling census of the whole african population . END
the population registration system still has important functions . END
it supplies local data which are useful in administration and which can be used as a basis for intensive studies in particular situations . END
it provides a frame for the sampling census . END
it also provides a frame within which the registration of vital events is gradually gaining force ( though one cannot expect to obtain reliable vital statistics in most parts of the congo from this source in the near future ) . END
it is still used in making current population estimates in UNK years , though the value of these estimates is open to question . END
finally , it may have certain very important , less obvious values . END
even though the registers may have an incomplete record of persons present in a particular area or include persons no longer living there , they contain precise information on ages , by date of birth , for some of the persons present ( especially children in relatively stable communities ) and supplementary information ( such as records of marital status ) for many others . END
the quality of the census data can , therefore , be greatly improved by the use of the registration records in conjunction with the field inquiries . END
furthermore , it may be possible to estimate the error due to bias in method ( as distinguished from sampling error ) in each of these sources , on such subjects as fertility , mortality , and migration during a given interval by using information from two largely independent sources in conjunction . in life we learn to play our roles and we `` freeze '' into patterns which become so habitual that we are not really aware of what we do . END

a more detailed description of dictionary operations -- text lookup and dictionary modification -- gives a clearer picture . END
text lookup , as we will describe it , consists of three steps . END
the first is compiling a list of text forms , assigning an information cell to each , and replacing text occurrences with the information cell assigned to the form of each occurrence . END

two very useful ways for modifying a UNK are the addition to the dictionary of complete UNK rather than single forms and the application of a single change to more than one dictionary form . END

even the states remain primarily in an assisting role , providing leadership and teacher training . END
federal assistance is limited to half of the total expenditure , and the state or local districts must pay at least half . END
the state may decide to encourage local programs by paying half of the cost , or the state may require the local district to bear this half or some part of it . END
throughout the history of the program , state government expenditures in the aggregate have usually matched or exceeded the federal expenditures , while local districts all together have spent more than either federal or state governments . END

the greatest impact of the UNK principle has been in initially encouraging the UNK states and school districts to spend enough to obtain their full allocation of outside funds . END

an extension of this program into the other distressed areas should be undertaken . END
some of this trend toward area vocational schools has been related to the problems of persistent labor surplus areas and their desire to attract new industry . END

the major weakness of vocational training programs in labor surplus areas is their focus on serving solely local job demands . END
this weakness is not unique to labor surplus areas , for it is inherent in the system of local school districts in this country . END
planning of vocational education programs and courses is oriented to local employer needs for trained workers . END
all the manuals for setting up vocational courses stress the importance of first making a local survey of skill needs , of UNK the growth of local jobs , and of consulting with local employers on the types of courses and their content . END

local jobs can be seen and counted , while opportunities elsewhere are regarded as more hypothetical . END
while the u. s. department of labor has a program of projecting industry and occupational employment trends and publishing current outlook statements , there is little tangible evidence that these projections have been used extensively in local curriculum planning . END
the u. s. office of education continues to stress local surveys rather than national surveys . END
this procedure is extremely shortsighted in chronic labor surplus areas with a long history of declining employment . END
elaborate studies have been made in labor surplus areas in order to identify sufficient numbers of local job UNK and future replacement needs for certain skills to justify training programs for those skills . END

moreover , the current information on what types of training are needed and possible is too limited and fragmentary . END
there simply is not enough material available on the types of job skills that are in demand and the types of training programs that are required or most suitable . END
much of the available information comes not from the federal government but from an exchange of experiences among states . END
state and local agencies in the vocational education field must be encouraged to adopt a wider outlook on future job opportunities . END
there is a need for an expanded federal effort to provide research and information to help guide state education departments and local school boards in existing programs . END
a related question is whether unemployed workers can be motivated to take the training provided . END
there is little evidence that existing public or private training programs have any great difficulty getting students to enroll in their programs , even though they must pay tuition , receive no subsistence payments , and are not guaranteed a job . END

local school districts are hard pressed financially and UNK about vocational training . END

state governments have been taking the lead in establishing area vocational schools , but their focus is still on area job opportunities . END

such training would increase the tendency of workers to leave the area and find jobs in other localities . END
a further possibility is suggested by the example of the g. i. bills and also by some recent trends in attitudes toward improving college education : that is to provide financial assistance to individuals for vocational training when local facilities are inadequate . END
this probably would require some support for subsistence as well as for tuition , but the total would be no greater than for the proposals of unemployment compensation or a youth conservation corps . END

we mentioned odd-lot indices a few paragraphs ago . END
in the stock market , the normal trading package is a hundred shares , just as 5,000 bushels is the standard grain contract package . END
a stock transaction for less than a hundred shares is executed via a special odd-lot UNK on the floor of the exchange . END
this results in a separate record being made , distinguishing these trades from the overall volume of trading . END
according to the theory underlying odd-lot indices , the trader who trades odd lots is most likely a small trader , one who can't afford to trade round lots . END

falling most easily prey to an adverse market movement , for this rank of traders can least afford to lose , virtually anything the odd-lot traders do , UNK , is taken to UNK the `` wrong '' thing to do . END
figures reporting the volume of odd-lot purchases and odd-lot sales are released by the stock exchange and carried in the newspapers . END
odd-lot index observers then make UNK of the data according to their particular statistical recipe . END
they might , for example , plot it exactly as is , or they might make ten day moving averages of it , or longer moving averages , or they might simply plot the ratio of odd-lot purchases to odd-lot sales . END
the particular recipe is a matter of individual taste . END
the data is now interpreted in conjunction with a price chart , usually of a popular stock average . END
towards the end of an intermediate or major rise , while the top is forming on the price chart , it is frequently observed that the odd-lot buying increases sharply . END
this UNK the UNK that the formation in progress is quite likely to be a top . END
similarly , at the opposite end of the market cycle , towards the end of an intermediate or major decline , usually while the bottom is being formed on the price chart , it is characteristic that an increase is noticed in odd-lot selling again alerting the UNK that a bottom is becoming a greater likelihood . END
thus , in the aggregate , the odd-lot trader is one who buys at the tops and sells at the bottoms , notwithstanding occasional individual exceptions . END

in assessing the outlook for interest rates in 1961 , the question , as always , is the prospect for general business activity . END
by and large , what happens to business as a whole will govern the relationship between demand and supply conditions in the capital markets and will thus determine interest rates . END
moreover , the trend of general business activity in 1961 will exert a decisive influence on fiscal , monetary , and other federal policies which affect interest rates . END
UNK has been a baffling year for analysts of general business activity . END
during much of the year the general level of business activity has moved along on a UNK UNK , but there have been persistent signs of slack in the economy . END
the tendency for general business activity to soften somewhat is becoming more evident . END
although the pause in the advance of general business activity this year has thus far been quite modest , it is hard to escape the conclusion that the softening process will continue into the first quarter of 1961 and possibly somewhat longer . END
it is difficult to see any powerful sources of strength on the horizon at this time which would give the economy a new upward thrust . END
the rate of plant and equipment spending by business and industry now seems to be UNK out and facing some decline . END
in earlier business cycles , when this occurred the country usually experienced a sharp upturn in residential construction as mortgage financing became easier to obtain . END

wage-price policies of industry are the result of a complex of forces -- no single explanation has been found which applies to all cases . END
the purpose of this paper is to analyze one possible force which has not been treated in the literature , but which we believe makes a significant contribution to explaining the wage-price behavior of a few very important industries . END
while there may be several such industries to which the model of this paper is applicable , the authors make particular claim of relevance to the explanation of the course of wages and prices in the steel industry of the united states since world war 2 . END
indeed , the apparent stiffening of the industry's attitude in the recent steel strike has a direct explanation in terms of the model here presented . END
the model of this paper considers an industry which is not characterized by vigorous price competition , but which is so basic that its wage-price policies are held in check by continuous critical public scrutiny . END
where the industry's product price has been kept below the `` UNK '' and `` UNK '' prices due to fears of public reaction , the profit seeking producers have an interest in offering little real resistance to wage demands . END
the contribution of this paper is a demonstration of this proposition , and an exploration of some of its implications . END
in order to focus clearly upon the operation of this one force , which we may call the effect of `` public-limit pricing '' on `` key '' wage UNK , we deliberately simplify the model by UNK from other forces , such as union power , which may be relevant in an actual situation . END
for UNK purposes , this is best treated as a model which UNK out the conditions under which an important industry affected with the public interest would find it profitable to raise wages even in the absence of union pressures for higher wages . END
part 1 , below describes this abstract model by spelling out its assumptions . END
part 2 , discusses the operation of the model and derives some significant conclusions . END
part 3 , discusses the empirical relevance and policy implications of the conclusions . END
part 4 , is a brief summary . END
the mathematical appendix presents the rigorous argument , but is best read after part 1 , in order that the assumptions underlying the equations may be explicit . END
1 , the assumptions of the model END
the industry with which this model is concerned is a basic industry , producing a substantial share of gross national product . END
price competition is lacking . END
for the purposes of setting the product price , the industry UNK as a single entity . END
in wage negotiations , the industry UNK as a unit with a single union . END
the demand for the industry's product END
we are concerned with aggregate demand for the industry's product . END
the manner in which this is shared among firms is taken as given . END
in any given time period , the aggregate demand for the industry's product is determined by two things : the price charged by the industry , and the level of aj . END
for the purposes of this discussion , the problem of relative prices is UNK in these two variables , since gnp includes other prices . END
( we abstract here from technological progress and assume that prices of all other products change proportionately . END
the form of the industry demand function is one which makes quantity demanded vary inversely with the product price , and vary directly with the level of aj . END
the industry of this model is so important that its wage and price policies are affected with a public interest . END
because of its importance , and because the lack of price competition is well recognized , the industry is under considerable public pressure not to raise its price any more than could be justified by cost increases . END
the threat of effective anti-trust action , provoked by `` UNK the public '' through price increases not justified by cost increases , and fears of UNK relations with customers , congress , the general public and the press , all operate to keep price increases in some relation to cost increases . END
for the industry of this model , the effect of such public pressures in the past has been to hold the price well below the UNK UNK price ( given the wage rate and the level of gnp ) , and even below the UNK price ( but not below average cost ) . END
for such an industry , it is only `` safe '' to raise its price if such an increase is manifestly `` justified '' by rising costs ( due to rising wages , etc. ) . END
thus , if public pressure sets the effective limit to the price that the industry may charge , this pressure is itself a function of the wage rate . END
in this model , we abstract from all UNK sources of cost changes , so that the `` public-limit price '' only rises as the wage rate rises . END
in such circumstances , it may well be to the advantage of the industry to allow an increase in the basic wage rate . END
since marginal costs rise when the wage rate rises , the UNK price also rises when the public-limit price is elevated , and is likely to remain well above the latter . END
the UNK price will also be raised for potential domestic competition , but unless general inflation permits profit margins to increase proportionately throughout the economy , we might expect the public-limit price to approach the UNK price . END
the UNK price would be approached more rapidly , since domestic UNK do not enter foreign costs directly . END
where this approach becomes critical , the industry can be expected to put much emphasis on this as evidence of its sincerity in `` resisting '' the wage pressures of a powerful union , requesting tariff relief after it has `` reluctantly '' UNK to the union pressure . END
whether or not it is in the industry's interest to allow the basic wage rate to rise obviously depends upon the extent to which the public-limit price rises in response to a basic wage increase , and the relation of this response to the increase in costs accompanying the wage increase . END
the extent to which the public-limit price is raised by a given increase in the basic wage rate is itself a function of three things : the passage of time , the level of gnp , and the size of the wage increase . END
we are UNK from the fact of strikes here , but it should be obvious that the extent to which the public-limit price is raised by a given increase in the basic wage rate is also a function of the show of resistance put up by the industry . END
the industry may deliberately take a strike , not to put pressure on the union , but in order to `` educate '' the government and the customers of the industry . END
as a strike continues , these parties increase their pressure on the industry to reach an agreement . END
they become increasingly willing to accept the price increase that the industry claims the wage bargain would entail . END
public indignation and resistance to wage-price increases is obviously much less when the increases are on the order of UNK per UNK than when the increases are on the order of UNK per month . END
the simple passage of an additional eleven months' time makes the second UNK boost more acceptable . END
thus , the public-limit price is raised further by a given wage increase the longer it has been since the previous price increase . END
notice , however , that the passage of time does not permit the raising of prices per se , without an accompanying wage increase . END
similarly , higher levels of gnp do not , in themselves , provide grounds for raising prices , but they do relax some of the pressure on the industry so that it can raise prices higher for a given wage increase . END
this is not extended to anticipated levels of gnp , however -- only the current level of gnp affects the public pressure against wage-price increases . END
finally , since the public requires some restraint on the part of the companies , larger wage increases call for less than proportionately larger price increases ( e.g. , if a wage increase of 5% allows a price increase of UNK , a wage increase of 10% allows a price increase of something less than UNK ) . END
we assume that average total unit cost in the relevant region of operation is constant with respect to quantity produced ( the average cost curve is horizontal , and therefore is identical with the marginal cost curve ) , and is the same for every firm ( and therefore for the industry ) . END
the level of this average cost is determined by factor prices , technology , and so forth . END
as we have noted , however , we are UNK from changes in all UNK of this level except for changes in the wage rate . END
the level of average cost ( equal to marginal cost ) is thus strictly a function of the wage rate . END
union policies and collective bargaining issues END
the single union which faces the industry does not restrict its membership , and there is an adequate supply of labor available to the firms of the industry at the going wage rate . END
the union does not regard unemployment of its own members as a matter of concern when setting its own wage policy -- its concern with employment makes itself felt in pressure upon the government to maintain full employment . END
the union vigorously demands wage increases from productivity increases , and wage increases to offset UNK increases , but we abstract from these forces here . END
for our present purposes we assume that the sole subject of bargaining is the basic wage rate ( not including productivity improvement factors or UNK adjustments ) , and it is this basic wage rate which determines the level of costs . END
productivity is something of an amorphous concept and the amount of productivity increase in a given time period is not even well known to the industry , much less to the union or to the public . END
disagreement on the amount of productivity increase UNK the problem of agreeing how an increase in profit margins related to a productivity increase should be shared . END
the existence of conflict and of vigorous union demand for an increase in money wages does not contradict the assumption that the union is willing to settle for UNK and UNK increases as distinct from a UNK increase in the basic wage rate . END
we assume further that the union recognizes the possibility that UNK increases may offset UNK increases , and it does not entirely disregard the effect of price increases arising from its own wage increases upon the `` real '' wage rate . END
for internal political reasons , the union asks for ( and accepts ) increases in the basic wage rate , and would vigorously oppose a reduction in this rate , but the adjustment of the basic wage rate upwards is essentially up to the discretion of the companies of the industry . END
changes in the basic wage rate are UNK , and they constitute an argument for raising prices . END
however , it is not known to either the union or the public precisely how much of a cost increase is caused by a given change in the basic wage rate , although the companies are presumed to have reliable estimates of this magnitude . END
in this model , then , the industry is presumed to realize that they could successfully resist a change in the basic wage rate , but since such a change is the only effective means to raising prices they may , in circumstances to be spelled out in part 2 , below , find it to their advantage to allow the wage rise . END
thus , for UNK changes in the basic wage rate , the industry becomes the active UNK , since any increase in the basic wage rate can occur only by reason of industry acquiescence . END
the UNK in the literature would appear to be that the basic wage rate would be unchanged in this case , on the grounds that it is `` clearly '' not in the interest of the industry to raise wages UNK . END
from this UNK it is an easy step to the conclusion that any observed increases in the basic wage rate must be due to union behavior different and more aggressive than assumed in our model . END
it is this conclusion that we challenge ; ; END
we do so by UNK the UNK on which it is based . END

in the century from 1815 to 1914 the law of nations became international law . END
several factors contributed to this change . END
the congress of vienna is a convenient starting point because it both UNK and symbolized what was to follow . END
here in 1815 the great nations assembled to UNK not merely for europe , but for the world . END
thus the congress marks a formal recognition of the political system that was central to world politics for a century . END
international law had to fit the conditions of europe , and nothing that could not fit this system , or the interests of the great european nations collectively , could possibly emerge as law in any meaningful sense . END
essentially this imposed two conditions : first , international law had to recognize and be compatible with an international political system in which a number of states were competitive , suspicious , and UNK in their political UNK with one another ; ; END
second , it had to be compatible with the value system that they shared . END
in both respects , international law was UNK . END
it was not always easy to develop theory and doctrine which would square the two conditions . END
on the one hand , the major european nations had to maintain UNK each other an emphasis upon sovereignty , independence , formal equality -- thus insuring for themselves individually an optimal freedom of action to maintain the `` flexibility of alignment '' that the system required and to avoid anything approaching a repetition of the disastrous UNK experience . END
but there was no pressing need to maintain these same standards with regard to most of the rest of the world . END
thus , theory and doctrine applicable among the great nations and the smaller european states did not really comfortably fit less developed and less powerful societies elsewhere . END
political interference in africa and asia and even in latin america ( though limited in latin america by the special interest of the united states as expressed in the monroe doctrine , itself from the outset related to european politics and long dependent upon the `` balance of power '' system in europe ) was necessary in order to preserve both common economic values and the european `` balance '' itself . END
a nation such as switzerland could be neutralized by agreement and could be relied upon to protect its UNK ; ; END

out of the question was the UNK of asia and africa . END
this UNK of the law was made explicit by a number of 19th century scholars . END
more emphasis was put upon the fact that international law was the law of `` civilized nations '' ; ; END

UNK stated that the public law was essentially `` limited to the civilized and christian peoples of europe or to those of european origin '' . END

now , with virtually every writer , not only was the european origin of public law acknowledged as a historical phenomenon , but the rules thus established by the advanced civilizations of europe were to be imposed on others . END
the european customs on which international law was based were to become , by force and fiat , the customs that others were to accept as law if they were to join this community as sovereign states . END

the law of nature governed UNK in their relationship to their own citizens , to foreigners , and to each other in a UNK unified system . END
